Praefatio.	Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After having completed this book for you, which is the last of the sciences in medicine with its supplement, and having reached the end of it through its expositions and its declarations, it seemed to me that I should complete it for you with this Treatise, which is a part of operation, namely, surgery with the hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Since surgery with the hand has been laid low in our region and in our time, and has been entirely privatized: perhaps the knowledge of it has perished, and its trace has been lost: and there remained from it only small descriptions in the books of the ancients, which were changed by hand: and they suffered error and hesitation, until their intentions were closed, and the vision of it was lengthened: It seemed to me that I should revive it with the order of this Treatise in it according to the way of its exposition, and declaration, and abbreviation: and that I should come with the forms of Cauterii's tools, and of the other instruments of work: since it is made from its declaration addition, and from its operation which is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	However, the reason why a good artisan of it with his own hand does not exist in our time is this: because the art of medicine is long, and it is necessary for its author to be exercised before that in the science of anatomy, which Galen narrated, until he knows the joints of the limbs, and their forms, and their connection and separation, and has knowledge of the bones, and of the nerves, and of the tendons, and of their number, and of their exits, and of the pulsatilae of the veins, and of the quiet places, and of the outlets of them.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And on account of this Hippocrates said that the name with the name is much, and with work is little, and especially in the art of the hand.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	We have indeed already spoken of that in the introduction of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	Since those who are not knowledgeable about what we have said about anatomy are not spared from falling into error, in which men perish: as I have seen many of those who are formed from this science, and boast about it without knowledge, and without experience.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	Which is, because I have seen a foolish doctor to lance a scrophulous abscess on the neck of a woman, and he happened to cut some arteries in the neck: therefore the woman's blood flowed, until she died between her hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I have seen another doctor who presumed to remove a stone from a man who had grown old, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	Therefore he reached him, and removed it with a fragment of the bladder.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	Therefore the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And indeed I had already been called to remove it: and I saw from the size of the stone, and the weakness of the sick man, that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I have seen another doctor who received a bribe from a certain duke of our land for medicine: and it happened to an eunuch black man who was with him, a fracture near the calcaneum in his leg: and the doctor rushed with ignorance, and he bound the fracture over the wound with bandages, and a strong binding, and did not let out the wound's expiration.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he cured him according to his own desires.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Then he sent him away for several days, and commanded him not to untie the bandage: and it remained thus until his leg became an abscess, and his foot, and it reached its destruction.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	I was called to him, and I hurried to untie the bandage: and peace followed, and he was freed from his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	However, corruption had already been confirmed in the member: and I could not restrain it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	Therefore, corruption ceased to walk in the member, until it died.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And I saw another physician who pierced the cancerous abscess: and it became inflamed after days, until its evil was revealed to its master.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	That is, because when the cancer is pure from humor melancholico, then it is not necessary to approach it with a knife at all, unless there is in the member that can bear, so that the whole of it be cut off.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And for that reason, my son, it is necessary for you to know that the operation with hand is divided into two divisions: namely, the operation to which safety is associated, and the operation with which there is danger in many positions.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I have already awakened in every place of this book, in which the operation comes where there is fear and fear.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Therefore it is necessary for you to beware of that and dismiss it, so that the fool does not find a way to speak and disgrace himself.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Take therefore the measure with solicitude and protection, and the sick of yours with facility and firmness, and use them the better way leading to grace of God for salvation and praiseworthy succession: and dismiss terrible afflictions difficult of healing: and take away your souls from that which makes you afraid, so that hesitancy may enter upon you in your faith and your advantage.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For it is rather remaining to your glory, and more exalted in this world, and finally to your quantities.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	Galen already mentioned this in some of his own admonitions.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	You shall not treat bad illness: lest you be called a bad doctor.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	However, this treatise has now been divided into three chapters.
Capitulum primum.	Chapter one.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	Of cauterizing with fire and of cauterizing with sharp medicine, chapters are arranged and ordered from the beginning to the end, including the forms of instruments and tools for cauterization, and everything necessary for the operation.
Capitulum secundum.	Chapter two.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	Of cutting and piercing, bloodletting and venting, and wounds: and extracting arrows, and similar things: and the whole chapter is arranged according to the forms of instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	Chapter three.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	Of restoration, and dislocation, and curing of twisting, and similar things: the chapter is arranged from the beginning to the end, and according to the forms of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	To God alone be glory.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	The Surgical Book of Albucasis.
Pars I.	Part one.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	Of the benefit and harm of cauterization: and with which constitutions it is suitable, and at what time: and if with iron or gold.
Caput I.	Chapter one.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But before I mention the operation with it, it is necessary to say the quality of its benefit and harm, and in which constitution it is displayed.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say therefore, that the speech about the quality of the benefit and harm of cauterization is a long and subtle, knowledge, and secret hidden.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	Also a multitude of wise men spoke about it, and they disagreed in it; and to me indeed it is enough little from their speeches, fearing the prolongation.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I say therefore, that the cauterizer universally combines with every composition, which is with matter and without matter: excepting two compositions, which are a hot composition without matter, and a dry composition without matter.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	However, in the hot and dry composition with matter they have disagreed.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	For some have said that the cauterizer is useful in it.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	And others said the opposite of that, namely that the cauterizer is not suitable for an illness, which is from heat and dryness: because the nature of fire is heat: and it is unsuitable, that one should be healed from a sickness of hot and dry, with hot and dry.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And he who says the opposite of that said: that by cauterizing, a remedy is made for every sickness of hot and dry, which happens in the bodies of men: because when you compare the body of man, and its humors, to the composition of fire, you find the body of man cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	And I indeed say by his word: because from experiment he has extracted that from me many times.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	However, it is not necessary, that he should come to that, unless who already tested, and trained in the chapter of cauterization exercise last, and knew the diversity of compositions of men, and disposition of sicknesses in themselves, and causes of them, and accidents of them, and time of them.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	From the other compositions however there is not upon you fear: and especially in sicknesses of cold and wet.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	For now all doctors have gathered upon them: and they have not disagreed in remedy with cauterization in them.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And know children, that from the secret of healing by cauterization with fire, and its goodness upon cauterization with burning medicine is: because fire is simple, whose action does not reach, except to the member which is cauterized: and it does not hurt another member joined with it, unless little harm.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	The action of burning medicine reaches to what is protruded from the limbs: and perhaps it causes to happen in the limb difficulty of healing, and perhaps it kills.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	Fire however, on account of its subtlety and goodness of its substance, does not do that, unless it overflows.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	Now indeed it has become known to us by experiment, because of the length of service and study with the art, and position above truth of things: and on account of that I excuse myself from length of speech.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if not, because it is not allowed to this my book, I would bring to you a secret hidden in fire, and quality of its operation in bodies of its expulsion, which expels difficulties by philosophical demonstrative speech, which would be remembered by your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And know, sons, that they themselves disagree in the time, in which it becomes to be done cauterization, and they put a better time for true.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	And I say, that cauterization becomes in every time: because harm accidentally happening because of time is submerged in advantage, which is drawn with cauterization.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	And especially if cauterization is because of pains from necessary pains, strong, urgent, who do not tolerate slowness: therefore because it is feared from them, that something evil happens which is greater, than small harm happening because of time.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And it does not fall in your minds, sons, that which they do not fear, except the crowd and stupid doctors, namely that to that difficulty which is healed by cauterization, there is not always return: and they put that following, and thing is not as they think: because cauterization is not, except in place of medicine, which changes complexion, and dries wetnesses which are cause, why pains happen.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	However, the cauterizing instrument exceeds medicine by its speed of health recovery, its effectiveness in operation, and its power of dominance: and it is possible for the illness to return at some time according to the infirmity's constitution, location, and nature, and what is prepared in his body from the accumulation of superfluities in him: and what reaches him in acquisition of his own from foods, and similar causes, unless illness occurs, in which cauterizing is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	Subtle illness in a member of few superfluities and moistures, such as tooth cauterizing due to pain, and similar causes, is possible for that pain not to return in it.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But that happens in few.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	Indeed, the common talk again, that cauterizing is the last of medicine, is correct speech: not to what they intend in it: because they believe that there is no cure that confers with medicine, nor with another after the fall of cauterizing.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	But the matter is contrary to that, and intention, that cauterizing is the last of medicine, is not, unless when we administer modes of cure in some illness, and those medicines do not conform: then we administer at the end of the matter cauterizing, and it conforms: then it falls, that cauterizing is the last of medicine, not according to the intention which the common people and many stupid physicians understand.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	The ancients said, that cauterizing with gold is better than cauterizing with iron: and they did not say this, unless because of the equality of gold, and sublimity of its substance: and they said, that it does not make pus a place of cauterizing.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	However, it is not absolutely true that it does not do that in certain bodies without other things.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And the cauterizing iron itself is good, and better than with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	However, when you heat the cauterizing iron in fire from gold, it is not indicated to you when it burns according to the amount you wish, because of the redness of gold: and when it approaches the heat, and if you add more fire to it, it melts in the fire, and turns into sheets.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Therefore, the craftsman falls from that into his trade: and for that reason, the cauterizing iron with iron is made by us faster and closer, from rightness to the operation.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	And indeed, I have already arranged this Chapter on Cauterizing, according to chapters: and I arranged them from head to foot: so that those seeking something from it might be helped.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	Of the manner of cauterizing a head at the commissural collar.
Caput II.	Chapter 2.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	This cauterizing applies to the dominion of moisture and cold over the brain: which are two causes of sweat, and multitude of humors flowing from the head to the parts of the eyes and ears, and multitude of sleeps, and pain of the teeth, and pain of the throat: and universally all kinds of distress, which occur from cold, such as paralysis, and sweats, epilepsy, and apoplexy, and similar to those distresses.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The manner of cauterizing is, that you command the sick one: so that he may be emptied in the first place with the cleansing solution of the head three nights, or four, according to what requires the virtue of the sick one, and his age, and his custom.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then instruct him to shave his head with a razor.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then make him sit between your hands in a square position, so that he has already placed his hands on his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the root of your thumb on the root of his nose between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Whenever your middle finger reaches that spot, mark it with a pen.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then heat the cautery iron, which has this form.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place it on the marked spot with the pen, with a descending motion, by which your hand is gradually tightened, and you turn it.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then quickly withdraw your hand, and look at the spot.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	If you see that the amount of bone from his head is equal to the amount of alquille or zeveherb, then withdraw your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, repeat your hand with the same iron, or with another one if it is cooled: until you see the bones that I told you.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take some salt and dissolve it in water, and drink it with the wound, and place it on the spot: and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then place the salted drink on top of it in butter, and leave it on the spot until the scab of the fire is destroyed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then care for it with the four-ingredient ointment until it heals.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	Now they have said that the more the wound remains open, the more it emits pus: therefore it is better and more beneficial.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And some of them said that the skin should be cauterized up to the bone: and the cautery iron should be held until something of the density of bone is burned.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then it should be scraped after that which was burned from the bone, then care for it.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	Some say that it is necessary for the cauterio to reach the deepest point, until an impression of a fork is made in the jaw, so that the jaw falls out, as if by a kirate: or an instrument like that which women place under their infants when they are learning to write: and they claim that from this place vapors escape from the head, and the wound remains open for a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then it should be treated until it is healed.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	To me, however, these two types of cauterio do not appear at all in most people, except according to the way of fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	And it is better for me to let go of it with its own health.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	For the head is weakened from the solution of its natural continuity: as we have shown in other members: and especially when the head of an infirm person is weak by nature: and indeed the first type of cauterio is more saving and better for me, and I use it: therefore I operate with it in health.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	§ On the method of cauterizing the head in the pain of the whole head.
Caput III.	Head III.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When there is chronic pain in the whole head: and it is prolonged in an infirm person, and he uses herbs, and cochlis, and caputpurgis, and oils, and emplastrums.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if he has already been cauterized with one cauterio, which we have mentioned, and does not give him anything from those: then consider.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the head of an infirm person is strong by nature, and is not weak, and has found a strong cold: then cauterize with another cauterio under it a little.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize it on top of all the horn of its own head with a cauterio, so that it does not penetrate the skin, and expose a quantity of bone, as we have mentioned.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And cauterize it with a single cauterizing instrument at the back of its head, in the place called the "neck": and it is the place where the windpipe is located. And elevate your mat with this, and do not expose its mouth.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	For indeed, it found itself in pain due to that very intense pain, and different from the pain of all other head cauterizations.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I will call this Cauterium in its place: and it must be a cauterizing instrument, by which the horns of the head are cauterized, and the back of its head is cauterized more delicately with a cauterizing instrument, by which the middle of the head is cauterized.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	On the method of cauterizing in headache, both with a burning medicine and with iron.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When pain and swelling occur in a part of the head, or the pain extends to the eye, and is evacuated with cleansing medicines for the head, and the remaining cure is administered, as I said in the divisions of ailments, and it is not all together: then cauterization in that place is done in two ways: either cauterization with a sharp burning medicine: or with iron.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	But the cauterizing instrument with a burning medicine is, as you take one tooth of garlic, and scrape it, and cut off its extremities from both sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then cut the place of pain at the time with a wide leech, until it becomes a place under the skin, in which the tooth is caught.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then introduce it into that place under the skin, until it is hidden: then bind it over it with a soft cloth, and let it go for fifteen hours, then dissolve it, and take out the garlic, and let it lie for two or three days: afterwards put on it a poultice soaked in butter, until the place becomes pus: then care for it with ointment until it is healed.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if you wish to do this with certain caustic medicines, which I have written about in my twelfth book on Burning Medicaments.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	However, the cauterization of it with iron is done in this manner.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	The cautery, which has this shape.
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	And it is called a Claw: because the shape of its head is like the shape of a claw, in which there is something of sharpness, and in the middle of it is a small elevation.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then place it on the spot, and hold your hand: and you will turn the iron gradually with speed: and the amount that is burned from the thickness of the skin, is like the middle of it.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And raise your hand, so that the artery, which is below, does not burn, and blood flow does not occur.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then immerse the wound in salt water, and place it on the spot, and leave it for three days: then place the wound with butter: afterwards care with ointment until it is healed.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if you wish, cauterize this hemicrania with the second edge of the knife of the cautery.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	And beware of the incision of the artery in this hemicrania, not anciently proper.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in an ancient hemicrania.
Caput V.	Chapter 5.
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When you are curing a hemicrania, since what we said from the previous cure, and what we said in the divisions of pains, and that cure does not help: and you see from the pain, that what we said first with medicine, or with the knife of the cautery with fire, then it is necessary to burn the knife of the cautery, until it becomes white after the signs on the spot with a line, whose length is the middle of a finger, or something like that: and place your hand twice, and tighten it until you cut the artery, and reach up to the bone.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	However, it is necessary for you to guard against the continuity of the jawbone, which moves during chewing, lest it be burned or a nerve that moves it be affected, from which spasms may arise.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	And this is above guardianship and precaution against the flow of blood from the severed artery.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	For in its severing there is fear, and especially for him who does not know what it does, and is not diligent or experienced: and he leaves the operation with it first.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I will come with the remembrance of the management of the flow of blood from the artery according to its own mode and in its place in this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	If you see from the pain that this cauterizer does not suffice for him, and you see the weak body bearing the cauterizer in the middle of the head, as we have narrated, care for the wound until it is healed.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you wish, administer the cauterizer which we said in the chapter of extracting the artery with a cauterizer having two knives.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For this cauterization is better and more fitting.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in pain of the Ear.
Caput VI.	Chapter 6.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When it happens to the ear that there is pain from cold, and it is cured with ointments, and the rest of the cure which we said in division, and the pain is not removed, then cauterize with fire: and this is called a puncture, whose form is thus.
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then the punctures with it after its ignition in the circumference of the ear entirely, as it is turned around: or in the circumference of both, if the pain is at the same time in both.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And draw yourself away from the root of the ear a little, after you have marked the spots with the cauterizer: and let the quantity of the cauterizer be ten punctures in every ear, and about thus.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	Then take care of the affected areas until they are healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	On how to cauterize in torture.
Caput VII.	Chapter 7.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	The torture that is cured with cauterization is only from certain types that occur from phlegm, as we mentioned in the divisions of ailments.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And the type of torture that lacks cauterization due to dryness and spasm of the nerve.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you treat this type of torture with honey, and head purgatives, and gargarisms, and your cure does not help, then it is necessary for you to cauterize the sick person with three cauterizations: one at the root of the ear, and the second a little lower from its time, and the third at the junction of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And place your cauterization on the opposite side of the weak part.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	Because softening does not occur except in the part that appears healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of cauterization is, that you cauterize the sick person directly at the tip of the upper ear under the horn of the head a little: and another in the time: whose length is according to the length of the thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And place your hand with the cauterization until half the thickness of the skin is burned.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the form of the cauterization, and it is a species from a knife, of which the form mentioned above is: however it is not too sharp like that: and it is necessary that the knife be a little without excessive coarseness.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then take care of the affected areas with what preceded until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	On how to cauterize in ancient apoplexy.
Caput VIII.	Chapter 8.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When ancient apoplexy is cured, and you treat it with what we said, and your medication does not help, and the sick person does not have a fever, then cauterize him with four cauterizations on all the horn of his head, and with the cauterization in the middle of his head, as we said, and with the cauterization in the back of his head, according to what preceded: and the method of cauterization should be according to what preceded.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	Even the cauterization with a cauterizer on the mouth of the stomach is done: and it is more final.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then it is treated, with that which preceded it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	On the method of cauterizing in the Oblivion.
Caput IX.	Chapter 9.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	It is necessary that in the drink first of all weak people be given great hira and cleaning pills for the brain.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then shave the head of the sick person all over, and place on his occiput the plaster of synapi described in the treatise on plasters: and place it several times.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	For this is indeed the method of cauterization: and do it according to order, as I said there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	If therefore he is healed by that, it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	If not: then do to him three cauterizations in the posterior part of his head, which are descending from the superior part of his head down to the lower part of his eye: and place between every cauterization the thickness of a finger.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then treat the cauterization, with that which preceded it.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	If however you wish an addition, and the sick person is able to bear that: then do to him a cauterization in the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	If however you wish an addition: then cauterize him over two horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then treat him, until he is healed: and let the cauterization be oily according to the form which was previously given.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	On the method of cauterizing in paralysis, and softening.
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	It is necessary that you proceed in the cleaning of the head with hira, and with that which we said.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then shave the head of the sick person: afterwards cauterize him in the middle of his head, and with a cauterizer over every horn of his head, and with a cauterizer on his back, and with three on his spines of his neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	If you lack the ability to tolerate many of these mollifications for the body and are weak, and the illness is strong: then cauterize him with four cauterizations on the spines of his back, and with the last one, until the skin is burned off as much as possible, and raise your hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then care for him until he is healed: and thus use the cauterizing iron.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	On the method of cauterization in epilepsy.
Caput XI.	Chapter 11.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	An epileptic should not be cauterized unless he whose epilepsy is from phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	Therefore, you should cleanse his brain first with heirba, and with the rest of the cure that we mentioned in the division, when he is weak and large, or is unable to bear the medicines.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	But if he is a child who does not bear the medicines, then a gargle is administered, and cleansing mastications of the brain are given before many days with good nourishment.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then shave his head, then cauterize him with a cauterizing iron in the middle of his head, according to what preceded in the method: and with another cauterizing iron in the back of his head, and on every horn of his head with the cauterizing iron.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	But if he is weak and strong, and is able to bear it, then cauterize him with the cauterizations that I said in having paralysis, and mollification of the body on the spines of his neck, and the spines of his back: and the cauterizing iron should be olive according to the mode that preceded.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	But if he is a weak child, then place the thin cauterizing iron in this way.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	On the method of cauterization in melancholy.
Caput XII.	Chapter XII.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the cause of melancholy is corrupted humors and thick phlegm, then cauterize it with the cauteries which we mentioned in having paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholy is excessive flow downward towards melancholy, and is a weak humid body, then give him to drink what cleanses his brain, according to what preceded in division: then shave the head of the weak one, and make afterward a well-made tortellini from linen, like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place it in the middle of his head: and the weak one sitting squarely should be held from every part.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then present the liniment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	And it is more fitting with butter of ancient olive oil.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And heat it over a fire with temperate heat measure, which the finger could tolerate when inserted into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then evacuate it in the middle of his head in a circle, and let him go until he is cooled.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Do this for the weak one once a week, with the rest of his good regimen, until he is healed.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you wish, cauterize it by making small points as much as possible, except that you hold the hand with the cauterizer: indeed it should be smoking.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	For this kind of cauterization humidifies the brain with quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then place on it a soaked cloth in butter, or chicken fat.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in descending water to the eye.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When the beginning of water in the eye is declared to you by signs which I mentioned in division, then begin and give the weak one to drink, with him what cleanses his head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And guard it from all moisture, and make it sit in the bath for several days while fasting.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then order him to rub his head and cauterize it in the middle of his head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize him over two temples with two cauteries, if there is the beginning of descent of water in both eyes at once: or from one side, if there is the beginning of water in one eye: and cut off with the cauterizer all veins and arteries that are under the skin: and let the cauterization be long in the width of the temples: and beware of bleeding.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	If you see anything from it, then cut it off immediately with any medicine that is possible: and I will come with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and cutting them off, and caution against bleeding.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And sometimes cauterize it on the back, under two bones, with two last cauterizations.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in tears anciently.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 14.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the tears of the eyes are ancient, constant: and they are on veins, and arteries that are in the manifest exterior of the head, it is verified that it is from superfluities cold, phlegmatic: then cauterize with the same cauterizer that I mentioned in the beginning of water descending, cauterizer in the middle of the head, and two cauterizations over two temples, and two cauterizations in the back under two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if you need addition, then cauterize it on every side of the eye carefully, over the extreme of the eyebrow with a small cauterizer.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in the discharge from the nose.
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you are treating that, when what we mentioned in the division, and the medication does not work: then hurry, and give to the sick person three nights of infirmocochias: afterwards shave his head, and cauterize it with a medium cauterizer, with an oil cauterizer.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize it with a claw cauterizer with two cauterizers, on two eyebrows under the hair a little.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And guard from the artery, that you do not cut it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	And this is the shape of the claw cauterizer.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	About the method of cauterizing in the softening of the eyelid.
Caput XVI.	Chapter 16.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the eyelid of the eye is softened from pain or moisture: then cauterize the eyelid with a cauterizer one, with this cauterizer lunar.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if you want, cauterize it above two eyebrows a little with two cauterizers in every part: and they will be lengthened from two temples: and the length of all cauterizer is according to the lengths of the eyebrow: and do not extend your hand with the cauterizer, but according to the quantity that burns the third eyelid.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	And this is the shape of the cauterizer according to this method of the lunar cauterizer.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	About the method of cauterizing the eyelid when hairs turn against the sharp eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter 17.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	The cauterizer in that is according to two methods: either the cauterizer with fire: or the cauterizer with burning medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	In the cauterizer however with fire, order the sick person before that, so that he may let go his hairs, if it is from those who cover them, until they are lengthened and equalized.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	If they prick him at the time of his birth: then bind his eyes with a cloth, so that they do not move, until they are born.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When they are born and have grown equal, then place the sick person's head in your lap: then mark the eyelids with a hot iron, mark it as it is according to the shape of the myrtle leaf: and let it be the beginning of the sign near the hairs.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then place a wet cloth soaked in albumin on the eye: or in the mucilage of psyllium on the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then with a hot iron, whose shape is this.
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then cauterize over the shape that you marked gradually on the eyelids, until the surface of the skin is burned, which is like the shape of the myrtle leaf, entirely visible.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the sign of the health of your work is: that if you see the eyelid of the eye already contracted, and the hairs raised at the point of the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	So raise your hand then: and let him go for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then place a cloth with butter on him until the eschar is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with ointment until he is healed.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	If any hair returns after an hour, and the eyelid becomes soft: then repeat the cauterizing iron on that place, as you did in the first time.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	If however the hairs are in the lower part: then cauterize that, until it is raised to its natural place: and equal it so that they do not prick the eye with the hairs.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	Concerning the method of cauterizing with a burning medicine in the same case.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	It is that you order the sick person, to let go the hairs, until they lengthen and become equal.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Prepare a form of a leaf from cloth using the pattern of a myrtle leaf.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take known soap and unsoaked lime from one ounce of each weight, or about that amount, and mix them well with good friction, and make it quickly, so that it does not cool down.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then take a piece of cloth from the one you made into the shape of a myrtle leaf, and place it on the eyelid of one or two eyes.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And place under the eye a wet compress soaked in egg white, and the sick person will be in your lap.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	And place your finger on the medicine and press it slightly.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And you should move it as often as the sick person feels the bite of the medicine, because its bite is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	Therefore, while he persisted in what he found the bite to be, then remove the medicine and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	Therefore, when the bite stops, then remove the medicine and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	And consider then, if you see the eyelid swelling, as it does with contraction with fire, or with incision, it is good: and if not, then repeat over it from the medicine on the place where it does not press the medicine and does not stain, until your operation equals and the eye closes.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then place a wet compress with butter on it until the burning of the skin is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with a diaphenic ointment or other, until it heals.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And it is necessary for you during the operation to keep the last guard, so that nothing falls into the eye from the medicine.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	If the eyelid becomes soft after days, and something fights from the hair in the eye, then repeat the medicine on that place which is softened from the eyelid properly, as you did at first.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of yourself until you are healed.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	And this is the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	And you should know that human eyes differ in size and shape.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore, according to that, your consideration should be: and the path of righteousness is not hidden from him who has a desire for this art.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	On the method of cauterizing in a lacrimal fistula.
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you are treating a fistula, since we mentioned in the divisions of diseases that your cure does not work, then you should cauterize it according to this method.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Tell the patient to place his head in your lap, and let him hold his head between your hands in this way, so that he does not move, nor move his head with his own.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then place a poultice of warm water on the eyeball, or in a mucilage of psyllium over his eye: then heat the cauterizing iron, whose form is this.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	Let it be concave, like the form of a penfeather of a turkey from one end, with which the cauterizing iron is made: and if you wish it to penetrate up to the other end, and if you wish it to go upwards, thus try.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	But this concave is better for your work.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Then express the fistula, if it is open, and remove the pus from it, and dry it: and if it is not open, then open it, and remove the pus from it.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then place then on it the cauterizing iron, which is made very hot.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	And hold with it your hand for a short time near the cauterizing iron, next to the eye, so that your hand does not wander, or disturb the patient: and place the cauterizing iron in the fat of the eye, and corrupt it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If you reach the beginning of your cauterizing tool up to your mouth, it will be good.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	And if not: then repeat the cauterizing tool once or twice, depending on what you need from it: and let it rest for three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then place a bandage with butter, and take care of it with drying ointment until it is healed.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	But if forty days have passed and it has not healed: then place a sharp corrosive medicine on top of it until the mouth is detached: and shave it according to how it came in its chapter.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another method of cauterizing a fistula, which some first said.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Bend to the location of the fistula, and find it: then place in the wound a thin tube, that is, a thin cannula, whose form is as follows.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour into it an amount of a liquid lead drachma, and hold your hand with the cannula retention good, and not move at all weakly, so that it does not run, or the liquid lead does not reach his eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	And you should place on the weak eye's bandage an infusion of egg white or in water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	For lead burns the location of the fistula, and heals it with a marvelous cure.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	But if the fistula is healed, with what we said from cauterizing and cure, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	And if not, then it is necessary to administer the nostril opening, and reduce the fistula to the course of the nose, according to how it comes to its own place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in lip wounds.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Often wounds occur in the lip that are called pimples, and especially in the lips of children.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When therefore you are caring for these fissures, since as we said in the division of diseases, it does not bring about a cure, then apply a small cauterizing knife with fire, according to this form.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And its concavity should be according to the thinness of the knife.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then place the burning knife quickly in the very fissures, until the cauterizing knife reaches the depth of the fissures.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with a bandage, until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	Concerning the method of cauterizing in a mouth ulcer.
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When an abscess occurs at the root of the gingiva, or in the palate, or in the roots of the teeth: then it discharges pus, and it is torn open: afterwards it is opened up, and pus runs out, and a fistula forms: then you should care for it, and it does not bring about a cure, then it is necessary that you apply a burning knife with fire, according to the amount that it can take in the fistula.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then insert the burning knife into the opening of the fistula, and hold your hand there, until the burning knife reaches the depth and end of it: do this once, or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then care for it after that, with what we said about curing until it is healed.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If therefore the pus is cut away, and it is healed, it will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if not, then it is necessary to uncover the place, and remove the bone of the rotten part according to what comes in its head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	Concerning the method of cauterizing in gums, and molten teeth.
Caput XXII.	Chapter 22.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the gum is molten due to moisture, and the teeth move, and you care for it with medicines, and it does not bring about a cure: then place the head of the sick person in your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then place the cauterizing instrument, which will be shown later, on top of the tooth, and quickly insert the hot cauterizing tool into it: and hold your hand there for a short while until you feel that the weak heat of the fire has reached the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And then lift your hand: and then repeat the cauterizing tool several times, according to what you wish.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then the weak one will fill his mouth with salt water, and hold it for an hour, and then spit it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	For the tooth is strengthened by movement, and the jaw becomes softened and contracted, and the corrupted moisture is dried up.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	Chapter on the method of cauterizing in tooth pain.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter 23.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When the tooth pain is due to coldness, or there is frost in it, or worms, and no cure is found with medicines: then the cauterizing tool is used in two ways: either with butter, or with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	But the cauterizing tool with butter is as follows: you take some liquid butter and boil it in an iron spoon or in a vessel.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take a piece of cloth, and wrap it around the tip of the spoon.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then dip it into the boiling butter: and place it on the painful tooth quickly, and hold it until it cools: then repeat it several times, until the power of the fire reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	And if you wish, dip a piece of cloth or a rag into the cold butter, and place it on the painful tooth: and place a burning iron on top of it until the fire reaches the depth of the tooth's concavity.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	But cauterization with fire is as follows: you direct it towards the nozzle of air, or the nozzle of iron.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And let there be something of a thickness in his body, so that the sharpness of the fire does not reach the mouth of the sick person.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then place the cauterizing iron, whose form will come: and put it on that tooth: and hold your hand, until the cauterizing iron is cooled.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Do this several times, for the pain will be removed, either on that same day, or on another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And it is necessary that in the impression of that cauterizing iron, the sick person fill his mouth with good borax, and hold it for one hour: then spit it out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	This is the form of the cauterizing iron.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Cauterize with whatever end you can, according to what is possible: and this is the form of the needle.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in strophuli.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When strophuli are from phlegm, and from cold humidities, and they are not obedient to digestion by medicines, and you want to quickly digest them: then place the cauterizing iron, whose form is this.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	Having two open ends, so that smoke comes out from the cauterizing iron from the other end: and put it on fire over the abscess once, and second, if you need it, until it reaches the depth of the abscess.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	If the abscess is small: then put the cauterizing iron according to the quantity of the abscess.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then let it go for three days, and put on it a compress soaked in an infusion of marshmallow, until what the fire burned is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then care for it with tooth ointment, until the form of the needle is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in rauco voice and constriction of breathing.
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25.
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When moisture accumulates over the bronchial channel, and especially when it is accompanied by a cold constitutional state, then it is necessary for the sick person to be evacuated first with dissolved medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.
