Then cauterize the affected area at the root of the throat in a depressed location: and be careful not to let the cauterizer reach the throat, nor in the skin, except for a small part of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then cauterize the affected area at the junction of the neck in the last spine of the back: and let the cauterizer be a narrow one according to the mode that preceded it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with what preceded it until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	On the method of cauterizing in illnesses of the lungs and coughs.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26.
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	When the cough and illness of the lungs are due to cold moistures, and the sick person does not have a fever, nor phthisis, and the illness is chronic: then cauterize it with two cauterizers above the backbone in depressed, loose, empty locations.
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	And with another cauterizer in the middle of the chest between two breasts: and let the cauterizer be a needle according to the form that preceded it.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	And if your cauterization is by pricking with the cauterizer called the Puncture, whose form preceded it in the pricking of ear pain: and let there be punctures from thirty punctures almost to another.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with what preceded it until it is healed.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	And now the cauterizer has three branches: according to this form.
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	Therefore it is alleviated with that cauterization when you do it with one triple cauterizer.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	In the treatment of cataract in the tilt-up method, in the case of dislocated humerus.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27.
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	When the head of the humerus is dislocated due to moisture and is not fixed at the time of its return from dislocation until it becomes a habit for him to return to its place, then when it happens as we have already testified, it should be reduced to its original position.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	Then the patient should lie on his back, or on the healthy side.
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	Then lift the cloth that is on the inside of the tilt-up to the upper part with your left hand fingers, and if the joint is dislocated to the inside.
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	Then take a cauterizing iron with two holes.
Cuius forma est haec.	Whose shape is this.
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	Then cauterize the cloth until it penetrates to the other side, and the figure of cauterization with four cauterizations will come.
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	And sometimes cauterization is done with a cauterizing iron having three holes, so the figure of cauterization then becomes six cauterizations: and they are holes according to the thinness of the thread.
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	And this is the shape of a cauterizing iron having three holes.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	And sometimes one is added to this mode, so there are eight cauterizations.
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	Then place salt-crushed onions on the cauterizing iron.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	Then make the patient stick to the quietness, so that the limb does not move during any time until he is strengthened.
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	And if the dislocation is to the upper part, and this rarely happens, then cauterize it on the arm with a claw iron, or with many puncturing cauterizations.
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	For the joint is strengthened, and the moisture is removed: and the patient is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	On the Method of Cauterizing the Stomach.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter 28.
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	When cold and excessive moisture occur in the stomach, until it is removed from its surroundings, and many catarrhs are multiplied to it, and continuous modes of treatment do not help: then it is necessary for the sick person to lie on his back, and extend his legs, and his hands.
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	Then cauterize with three cauteries, the cautery under the collarbone in the amount of one finger's breadth with the cautery hook, and two cauteries below from both sides of the cautery of one, until the figure of the cauteries triangular comes.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	And lengthen between each one so that they do not touch when they make pus.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	And the depth of the cautery should be the amount of two-thirds of the thickness of the skin.
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	And the shape of the cauteries should be according to this form without addition: and if you wish to cauterize with a large cautery in the middle of the stomach according to this form: and the cautery should be one according to the shape of a circle according to this form.
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	And the stomach should be cauterized by pricking it with the one that is farthest from this cautery: and there are signs on the stomach of a prick according to the amount, which you wish with the encaustic: then cauterize it with the cautery of the prick: then treat it with the treatment that preceded until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	On the Method of Cauterizing a Cold Ear.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter 29.
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	When pain occurs in the ear from cold and moisture, or from excessive thickening, until it exits its natural exit excessively, and the sick person is cured, with what we said, and does not improve in that: then it is necessary for the sick person to lie on his back, and signs with the encaustic three cauteries according to this form, and the same amount of cauteries below the clavicle, where the arm of man reaches: and there should be space that is the thickness of one finger between each cauterium: and the cautery should be according to the straight length of the body: and do not press your hand with the cautery too much.
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	And let the quantity of that which is burned be from the thickness of the skin, and the quantity of its middle not added: and let it be an invalid standing on its feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	But if it is not standing, then it is lying, who has already extended its legs and raised its arms.
Haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of the cautery.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	And indeed it is possible for you to cauterize this cautery with a scalpel, when you are skilled and prudent in the art.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	And guard yourself, so that you do not proceed to cauterization to the end, and the thickness of the skin is completely burned, why the whole body is burned, and it reaches the intestines: for the skin there is thin, so you know that.
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	¶ On the method of cauterizing abscesses in the liver.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	When it happens, and you want to know if that abscess is in the flesh of the liver, or in its tunic: then if it is in the flesh of the liver, the sick one suffers a sharp pain, and there is gravity without sharpness: and if it is in the tunic of the liver, with pain there is very sharp intensity: and you already see that its treatment has exhausted the doctors.
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	Therefore it is necessary for the invalid to lie on his back.
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	Then the shape of the abscess with the cautery: then burn the scalpel which is similar to a ray.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	And cauterize with that cautery one, until the whole skin is burned, and it reaches the intestines, until all the pus comes out: then care for him with the treatment of the sick, until he is healed.
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	And it is not necessary to use this cautery species, unless whose study in the art of medicine is prolonged: and through whose hand these ailments with some experiments often come: then he dares to do this operation.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	In fact, it is better for you to leave it with me.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	On the method of cauterizing in pleurisy.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	The ancients said that a cautery with the roots of Aristolochia should be applied to pleurisy in this way:
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	And it is that you should take from the dry roots of Aristolochia a long one, as long as a finger, and it should be as thick as the size of a finger.
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	Then dip it in oil: and burn it in the fire.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	Then cauterize it with one cautery in that which is between the connection of the wings with the neck, and two small cauteries under the guides a little inclined to the part which is under the chin.
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	And two cauteries also in that which is between the fifth and sixth ribs a little inclined to the backs: and with one cautery in the middle of the chest, and with another above the stomach.
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	And three cauteries from the backs: one in that which is between two spatulas: and two cauteries from both sides of the chest, lower with the cautery which is between two spatulas.
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	And it is not necessary to press your hand with the cautery, rather it should be in plain sight on the skin smoking.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	And some ancients have said that there are people who use a cautery from iron like a ray: and they burn, and they put it inside in that which is between the ribs, until it reaches with it to the swelling, and the pus comes out: as we said in the abscess of the eye.
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	But in this puncture with the cautery there is fear that either the sick person dies immediately, or it happens a fistula in the place which has no healing.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	32nd Chapter on the Method of Cautery for the Spleen.
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	When you are treating the affliction of the spleen, since as we mentioned earlier, the cure lies in the division of afflictions, and your treatment does not bring relief, then cauterization is necessary in it according to three methods, all of which are correct.
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	One of these methods is to perform three or four cauterizations along the length of the spleen according to the shape of the liver cauterizations, preceding in the same figure.
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	And there should be a certain amount of thickness between each cauterization, about the size of a finger, or slightly more or less.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	And the method of cauterization should be equal to that which we mentioned for the liver cauterization.
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	And do not press your hand against the cauterizer: and let the patient be weak and lying on his back.
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	Another method of cauterization is: to ignite the cauterizer having two wounds, as we mentioned in the chapter on dislocation of the shoulder: and raise the skin which is directly over the spleen where the arm of the weak left side reaches: and your elevation should be according to the width of the body, so that the cauterizations fall according to the length of the body.
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	Then insert two burning wounds until you penetrate the skin from the other side: then remove the cauterizer: thus four cauterizations are made.
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	And if you wish to cauterize with another cauterizer having three wounds.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	Then care for the cauterizer after you have released it: to emit pus for many days, for it is more beneficial than all the other things that preceded from the cure.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	33rd Chapter on the Method of Cautery in Hydropsy.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33.
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	The cauterizer does not fall into hydrocephalus unless properly anointed.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	When you treat hydrocephalus with the methods of cure mentioned in the division, and do not find a cure, then it is necessary to cauterize it with four cauterizations around the navel, and one cauterization on the stomach, and one on the spleen, and two cauterizations after the back between the vertebrae, and one in direct pectoris, and one in direct stomach: and let the depth of the cauterization be close to the thickness of the skin.
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	Then let the cauterizer leave the wound open, so that it can emit pus over time.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	And do not remove the patient from treatment after cauterization with him, for it is necessary that two intentions gather to him: and he will quickly come to him with the help of God.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	Indeed, the form of the cauterizer with which the belly is cauterized should be closed, according to its previous form: and the form of the one with which the back is cauterized should be oily, according to its previous form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	¶ On the method of cauterizing feet and legs.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter 34.
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	When boils form in hydrocephalus and are filled with yellow water, it is necessary to cauterize on the back of the foot in the nocrati, which is between the auricular and anular: and lift your hand with the cauterizer, and do not twist it: then lift your hand: and do not rub it at all.
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	For yellow water does flow out, and the cauterizer should be in this form.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	Then do two cauterizations on both legs in every leg, and let the cauterizer be made with the extreme end of the cauterizer: and let the cauterizer be made according to the length of the leg, one under the knee, and the other below it, around the middle of the leg: and two cauterizations on every hip: and let the cauterizer be left open without treatment for a long time, so that some water flows out from it: then cure it with the rest of what we said.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	Translation: "On the Method of Cauterizing in the Treatment of the Belly.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 35.
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	When there is a solution of the belly due to cold and moisture, until it weakens the retentive and digestive powers that are in the stomach and intestines: and it is cured with this method of cure, but not healed: and you see an infirm person tolerating a cauterizing instrument of excessive power, then cauterize him with a great cauterizing instrument above his belly, according to what preceded in the cauterization of the stomach with the cauterizing circle, and four cauterizing instruments in the circumference of the umbilicus, with the fine cauterizing hook: and cauterize him with a great cauterizing instrument above the alhosos, or with two cauterizing instruments.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	And if you see excessive moisture and he is tolerating that, then cauterize him with a cauterizing instrument above the comb, and cauterize him on every side: and perhaps add two small cauterizing instruments near the great one on his belly.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	For it is a cure that is advancing, whose momentum does not err.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	Translation: "On the Method of Cauterizing Hemorrhoids.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 36.
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	When in the anus there are many old hemorrhoids, or one, and they are from thick humors, cold, or corrupt moisture, and they are cured with what we said in division, and not by cure: then cauterize them with three cauterizing instruments on the lower spondyle of the back under the almeidati a little triangularly, and cauterize under the umbilicus almost two fingers.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if you think that his stomach is cooled and his food is not digested, and you see his face swelling, then cauterize him on his belly with a great cauterizing instrument, according to what preceded: and cauterize above his spleen, and another above his splenius muscle, with the fine cauterizing hook: and leave the cauterizing instrument open for some time: then cure him, until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	On the method of cauterizing an ulcer after its incision.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 37.
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	When you have incised the ulcer, then apply the cauterizing iron which resembles a needle.
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	Then insert the burning iron into the incised ulcer: and with your last hand, until the cauterizing iron reaches the opening of the vein from which the blood flowed, do it once or twice.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	If therefore the ulcers are many, then cauterize each one according to what we have related.
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	Then care for them, with that which heals them from the ointments, until they are healed.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if you cauterize him with a large cauterizing iron above the skin, it is more painful.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	On the method of cauterizing a fistula in the anus.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter 38.
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	When a weak patient does not obey the incision and operation which we have related in its place, and is frightened by it, perhaps he may be healed with the cauterizing iron.
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	Therefore when a fistula occurs and is old, pus flows from it, and corrupted moistures.
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	Therefore it is more appropriate that you probe it with a thin probe.
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	Then know the quantity of its depth with the probe.
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	Then apply the burning iron which is like a needle.
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	Then insert the burning iron into the fistula and the quantity in which it entered the closure.
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And repeat the burning iron over it, until those corrupted bodies are consumed, once or twice or three times, according to the quantity of your need.
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	And guard yourself from burning the nerve, if it is there, or the great vein: or if the fistula goes to the body of the bladder, or to the body of the intestine, then guard yourself from all these places.
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	And you shall not do this, unless when there is a fistula in a fleshy place: and you think that it is not penetrating.
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	Then take care of the place until it heals.
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	But if the place is sealed and the materials are removed from it, and it remains like this for a long time: then you will know that it has healed completely.
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And if the materials are not removed from it, then you will know that it is penetrating, or there is a rotten bone in its depth, or something like that from them: whose memory will come back to its place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	About the method of cauterizing the kidneys.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter 39.
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	When pain occurs in the kidneys due to cold, or heavy dampness, and it is weakened because of this: then you should cauterize the same above the almethenum on the kidneys, with a cauterizing iron over all the kidney with a claw, whose memory has been mentioned.
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	And perhaps we should cauterize it again in the same place.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	Therefore, three lines will come.
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	Therefore, they will be more effective in the bandage.
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	About the method of cauterizing the bladder.
Caput XL.	Chapter 40.
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	When weakness occurs in the bladder, and softening from cold and moisture, until it does not retain infirm urine, then cauterize it in the lower part of the inguinal on the bladder, where the pili pectinis begin, and with a cauterizing iron from the right inguinal, and another from the left of that: and the length of that cauterization should be according to the width of the little finger: and cauterize it with a cauterizing iron on the lower back, or with two cauterizing irons if you need them: and it should be according to what has been mentioned about the claw.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	On the method of cauterizing the uterus.
Caput XLI.	Chapter 41.
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	When fever and moisture occur in the womb and prevent pregnancy, destroy its menstruation, delay its call, and cause pain upon its arrival, then it is necessary to cauterize the womb with three cauteries around the navel, as we mentioned in the cauterization of the bladder, and with a cauterizing iron on the lower back, or with two cauteries: and let the cauterizing iron be tight.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	On the method of cauterizing the anus in dislocation.
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42.
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	When moisture is poured into the anus and becomes a cause of its exit from its place, and the sign of this is that the leg is stretched out over the other when compared together: and the place of dislocation is found to be empty in it.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	Therefore it is necessary to cauterize the affected person on the anus of its own with a similar cauterizing iron in a circle: after you sign with the encaustic in the circumference of the anus, as it rolls: and so that the cauterizing iron falls in the middle of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	And let the cauterizing iron be of the same shape as in the cauterization of the stomach.
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	If this cauterizing iron is not present to you, then cauterize it with three cauteries, with a large olive-oil cauterizing iron: and let the depth of the cauterizing iron be according to the thickness of the skin of the whole.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	On the method of cauterizing in sciatica.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter 43.
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	When pain occurs in the anus and the causes are fever and moisture: and the affected person is cured with it, as we mentioned in the division, and does not recover, and it returns: then it is necessary to dissolve the affected person from thick humors with fetid pills, or with artificial pills, and similar.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	Then cauterize him.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	And the method of cauterization in it is according to two methods: either a cauterizer with burning medicines, or a cauterizer with fire.
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	A cauterizer with fire is according to many ways.
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	One of which is, to cauterize on the anchor's pitch above three triangular cauterizations, in this form.
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	And make them a good or bad depth.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	And let the space be as much as the quantity of the thickness of a finger: and let the cauterizer be oily.
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	Sometimes however the cauterization is made in the middle above the anchor's head.
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	Therefore there are four cauterizations.
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	And if you want to cauterize with a circle, whose form precedes in the cauterization of anchor's dislocation, one: so that it contains the whole anchor.
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	And burn the thickness of the skin throughout.
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	This is the method of cauterization in Sciatica, when the pain adheres to the anchor itself, and does not extend up to the hip and leg.
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	If however it extends up to the hip and leg, then cauterize him with two cauterizations on the hip, on the place where the weak one indicates, in which is the pain, and with your cauterizer on the thigh four fingers towards the silvester part: and let the cauterizer be a knife.
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	And let the depth of the cauterization be according to the thickness of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	If the weak one indicates that the pain extends up to near the toes of the foot, then cauterize him there where he indicates with your cauterizer, three, or four, or more, if it needs it.
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	And if he indicates that the pain is under the knee towards the leg, then cauterize him there with your cauterizer one knife.
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	And beware in all your cauterizations, so that you do not burn the nerves or a large artery, and pull through it over an injured person, causing more harm or contraction.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	And indeed I have seen one and another of those who cauterized above the ankle, and they perished in the cauterization, and the leg became inflamed, until a tumor formed at the foot, and it was completely pierced through, and the entire foot rotted: then dissolution of the belly followed, and death after that.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	If the pain is in both parts at once, cauterize each according to this method.
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	And some wise men said about the cauterization of the ankle, which is this method of cauterization.
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	Make a similar sponge from iron, whose diameter is the middle of the palm: and let it be at its opening according to the thickness of the nucleus of the finger, or a little less: and inside that sponge let there be another sponge.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	And let there be space between each sponge that is the thickness of a finger joint: and let the sponges be open from both parts: and let their height be like a knot, or two knots: and make them handles from iron fitly adapted in the sponges.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	Then let it be heated in the fire until it reddens, and let it throw sparks: then let it be placed on the poultice of the ankle of the weak person lying on their healthy side.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	Then cauterize him with three round cauteries in one stroke.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then let him rest for three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	Then apply plasters with butter: and let the wound open be left for many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound with ointment until it heals.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	Albucasis says, "In this manner of cauterization, my son, we have been very little used, due to the terror of its appearance; and therefore, because few people find it bearable to endure over it.
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	Nevertheless, it is from good cauterizations that one who undergoes it finds and discovers with it a place for it.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	The cauterizing instrument with medicines adhering to it is made by you, who make two smears having a perforated ring, into which the card of its gate descends from the air or iron, length of the wall: whose height they are two knots, or as if they were themselves.
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	And let there be space that is the amount of thickness of a finger between both quantities of thickness, and be open below and above: and let it contain themselves adjacent to each other, according to this form.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	Then lay it on the pepper box anchor, leaning on the sound side.
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	And press your hand on the pepper box anchor much.
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	Then pour between the two circles from hot water, which is heated with fire for a little while, and hold it for a temporal amount of time: and the sick person tolerates its bite and its burning, because he found the bite like fire, until the bite is quiet.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	Then wash your hand with the instrument, and remove the hot water from the anchor entirely with sweet water: then let it go for three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	And put on it butter, until the blackness of burning is removed: and let it go for several days, and drain out pus from it.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	For it is the last in the bandage.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointments until it heals.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	If the pain extends to the hip or leg, make a stance in what contains water, according to what you did in the equal anchorage.
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	And this is the method of hot water: and I have already written it in the treatise on the rectification of medicines.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	Take alkali and unextinguished lime, each one part of the same: grind both, and place them in a new pot, whose lower part is perforated with a small hole according to the quantity that enters itself radius: and place under the bottom of the pot another glass pot: and throw on top of the alkali and lime from sweet water, which submerges both through a finger: after which you press it with your hand good compression: and leave the pot until the sharp water descends lower part of the glass pot.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	Then gather that water all, and throw it on top of another lime: and cook, until it is renewed.
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	For it will then be very strong acidity, which is administered in many medical operations, and in the cauterization of the remaining limbs.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	Because it performs the operation of its fire.
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	And from the medicines with which the anchorage are cauterized, also as tisis, and honey of cashew, and lime with soap, so that both are mixed.
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	And indeed Galen himself reported, of a certain man from ancient cure, by which he was cured of the pain of the anchorage and sciatic vein: and magnified it to be very good.
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	And he said, because it did not require other cure, and because he was healed from one vice, until he reported, because perhaps himself entered the bath carried, and exited from it already healed.
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	And it is also taken from the fresh sedategrass: and if it is not found green, a dry recent one is taken, and it is pounded much with some fat, and it is placed on the splint where there is pain, or in the leg, or in the hip: and it is bound, and it is let go for the quantity of three hours, or for the quantity that the sick person feels sedation of the burning.
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	Then introduce him into the bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	And when his body becomes moist, introduce him into a bed.
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	For the pain retreats, and he is healed.
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	And you should know that it is not necessary for someone to use a cautery with these medicines, unless after the evacuation of the body.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	And Dioscorides who said that, when the droppings of a goat are applied with it to the sciatic nerve, they bring him: and the cautery is made in this way.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	Take wool, and it is poured with old oil, and it is placed on the deep place which is between the thumb of the foot, and between the toes, and it is near the toe.
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	Then take the dry droppings of a goat, and burn it in fire, until it becomes coal.
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	Then place it on the wool, and let it go, until it is extinguished.
Deinde itera illud.	Then repeat that.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	And do not stop doing that, until you reach the sense above the splint, and the pain is quiet.
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	And this method of cautery is called the cautery of the goat.
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	About the cauterization of the back pain.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 44.
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	Sometimes pain occurs in the back from many causes, or from an accident, or from a blow, or from an excessive evacuation, and from similar things, from the infusion of cold and wet matter: and the cautery does not fall, except in this species alone, which is made from the infusion of cold matter.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	After the evacuation of the sick person with fetid pills, and similar ones, it is necessary to place three lines across the back, where the pain is located, according to the width of his ribs, after marking them with a hot iron in every line, five or more cauterizations according to the amount that comes from the tolerance of the sick person due to its virtue: and let the cauterization be made with a cauterizing needle.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, cauterize with three or four cauterizations, with a middle cauterizing needle, in this form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	On the method of cauterizing in the beginning of gibbosities.
Caput XLV.	Chapter 45
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	This illness often occurs in small children.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	And the sign of its beginning in children is: that a stricture occurs on him during breathing and movement, and it is found in the last rib and its nodes, which has already begun to rise above the other ribs.
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	When therefore you see this, and wish to do it, then cauterize that with a cauterizing needle which is a circle in this form.
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	And let him take the cauterizing needle over all part of the rib equally: and if you wish to cauterize around the rib with a cauterizing needle two lines, or three: and they should be close to each other.
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	Then take care of the place, until he is cured with that which we said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	And beware, do not administer the cauterizing needle in gibbosities, which is made in a spasm of the nerve.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	On the method of cauterizing in gout, and pains of the joints.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter 46
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	When pains of the joints are from humidities cold, which are poured out to each limb of the body, then when they occur in the feet, it is the custom of physicians to call that gout properly.
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	When therefore treating Gout of the cold cause and with methods of cure, and the pains do not subside, then the cauterizer will remove them.
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	And it is, that the cauterizer him after evacuation in the circumference of the joints of the feet, with many cautery: and let the cauterizer be olive oil.
Cuius haec est forma.	His this is the form.
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	And if you lack to points on the face of the foot, then make with cauterizer point.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	But if the pains ascend up to the knees, or other joints, and this often happens, then cauterize him above all the knee with three cautery, or four from every part, with this same cauterizer Clavi.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	But if you need more of this cauterizer, then cauterize him.
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	And do not submerge your hand with cauterizer, but rather it is about the thickness of the skin only.
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	But if the pains ascend up to the knees, and back: then administer what we said from cauterizer in his chapter.
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	But if the pains are only in the hands: then points in the circumference of the wrist, as two lines turn.
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	But if there remains from the pains in the fingers: then points them, over all the node point, and over the comb of the hand.
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	But if the pains ascend up to the elbows, or shoulders, then cauterize both from every part.
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	And do not evacuate the sick person from good diet, from reception of medicines.
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	For if good diet is made, and the phlegm is evacuated, he will be cured with the help of God with this cauterizer.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	¶ Of the manner of cauterizing in Hernia.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter 47.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	When a rupture occurs in the groin, and the intestine or bladder descends to the testicle, and it is close to the beginning: then you should advise the weak patient to abstain from food on his day of fasting.
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	And let him use laxatives to facilitate the descent of feces from his intestine.
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	Then let him sit between your hands on his back: and advise him to hold his breath until the bladder or intestine appears.
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	Then reduce it with your fingers, and mark with a red-hot iron under the rupture on the tongue with a sign indicating which end is similar to the middle of a circle towards the upper part of the body.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	Then heat the iron, which has this form, until it turns white, and throw sparks.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	Then reduce the intestine or bladder to its natural shape.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	Then let him place his hand on the spot where the intestine should not exit: and you have already opened between the legs of the weak patient, and placed under it a pillow, and another servant on his legs, and another on his chest who holds his hand.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	Then place the iron on the sign over him, with your hand holding the iron straight.
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	And hold him until you reach the mouth with it: or repeat with it another time if you have not reached the mouth with it in the first attempt up to the mouth.
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	And carefully observe the exit of the intestine during your burning, lest you burn it and cause death or great harm to the weak patient.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	And know that when you do not reach the mouth with the iron, your operation is incomplete.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	And it is necessary that the cauterizing instrument for children be thin, according to their size.
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care with the other ointments, until healing occurs.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	And let him be weak lying on his back for forty days, until the wound is sealed.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	And it is necessary to give his food in the length of time for his healing, which soothes his stomach: so that the intestine does not go out during defecation and excretion.
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	Then when he wants to rise after forty days, then give him a well-made bandage, and let him hold it for another forty days.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	And reduce his labor, and from the filling of food and drink, and from loud voices.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	For when he uses this regimen, thus he is healed with complete healing.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	And I will say the cure for hernias with incision in his chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	When however the hernia occurs in the remaining belly, and they are beginning, and you want them not to be added, then cauterize his hernia with a round cauterizing instrument according to its quantity: and let that which is burned from then be as the third of it.
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	Then care for him, with what we said: and not added.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	And now some of the first have said: to cauterize the hernia with a triangular cauterizing instrument, according to this form.
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	After it is signed with the cauterizing iron, and a line which is through the width in the upper side of the hernia, and another line below.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	And place your hand in the middle with the closed cauterizing iron.
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	But the first cauterizing instrument is easier and better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	About the method of cauterizing for pain due to a fall, or blow.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII.
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	When it happens to some members by accident or from a blow, and the pain persists for a long time and does not improve with medication, then it is necessary to cauterize with the point of a needle.
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	And the cauterizing instrument should be of the same size and strength as the member, its weakness, its virtue, its twisting location, and the pain it causes.
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	If therefore it is cured from the first cauterization, it is well.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	If not: then repeat the cauterization over it.
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	Because of the habit of these pains, it is customary for them to change from the member to that which approaches it.
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	Therefore it is necessary to follow them with the cauterizing instrument until the sick member is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	§ On how to cauterize in leprosy.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter XLIX.
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	However, sometimes the leprosy is healed by the greatest cauterization.
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	And especially the species of leprosy that is caused by the putrefaction of phlegm and melancholy, therefore when you want to cauterize it, consider.
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	If therefore the leprosy is incurable, and you have treated it with what we said in the division, and it has not descended nor stood still, and you fear that corruption will spread over the whole of its complexion: then cauterize it on the head with five cauterizations: one in the middle of the head, and the second below it towards the front at the end of the hair, and two on the two horns, and one behind on the nape of the neck.
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	And finally your hand with the cauterizing instrument for a short time, until it makes an impression in the mouth, and the bones are dislocated from it: so that the expiration of thick vapors is relieved from it, and also cauterize the spleen with the cauterizing instrument according to what preceded.
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	If the leprosy has already spread over the sick person and is clearly visible, then it is necessary to cauterize with these cauterants, which we mentioned at the head, and a cauterant on the tip of the nose, and two cauterants on the two maxillae, and two cauterants on the spines of the neck, and six on the spines of the back, and one large one on the buttocks and one above it, in the same place: and two on the ankles: that is, on every ankle, and one on each knee, and two on the shoulders, and two on the elbows, and two on the chest, and two on the tendons of his chest. And cauterize him over all the joints, from the joints of his fingers and toes: and cauterize over all the heels of his feet, and the palms of his hands.
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	And spare you the nerves that are above the last calcaneus, so as not to burn them.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	And sometimes he is cauterized with a cauterant on the tooth, and another on the stomach, and another on the ear.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	And know that the more you add a cauterant, the more it is a remedy and the more it benefits.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	And know that the sick person does not find pain in the cauterant, like healthy people do: because his body is already numb.
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	And it is necessary that the cauterants be of a size and proportion according to his limbs and joints: according to what preceded from the kinds of tools.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for the cauterant with flour of herb and honey, and the rest of the cure, until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in a stupor.
Caput L.	Chapter L.
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	When a certain limb is numb and is treated with medicines, oils, and plasters, but does not heal, then cauterize the numb limb with cauteries, according to the size or soundness of the limb.
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	And let your cauterizing tool penetrate slightly into the thickness of the skin.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it heals.
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	And sometimes cauterize for a certain numbness that occurs in the hand and foot, at the spine's exit of the nerves that move that limb: and the numbness will be removed.
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	But do not presume over it, unless he is wise in the knowledge of limbs and the exit of nerves that move the body.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	§ On the method of cauterizing in Albaras.
Caput LI.	Chapter L.
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	When Albaras is discolored and does not bring anything from the skills of medicine: then cauterize it with a deep cauterizing tool slightly, according to the thickness of the skin, until the whiteness is removed, and its color changes.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with flour of herb, and lentils with rose oil, and leaves of arnoglossa, and blood of dove, and blood of goose: each one is a part of one: mix all these, and apply them to cloth, and stick to the place, until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	§ On the method of cauterizing in Cancer.
Caput LII.	Chapter LII.
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	When Cancer is beginning and you want to stop it: then cauterize it with a cauterizing tool of a circle around it, as it turns.
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	But the wise say, that it should be cauterized with the last cauterizing tool in the middle.
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	To me, however, it does not seem that way: because I fear that it would become inflamed, and I have already seen this thing several times.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	And it is more correct to cauterize around its circumference with a circle, as we said, or with multiple cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in Adubelati.
Caput LIII.	Chapter 37.
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	When someone has an Adubelati and it is delayed in maturation, either due to excessive moisture causing it, or due to the age of an infirm person, when he is old and has little blood, or due to time, and you wish to hasten in the maturation of Adubelati, then cauterize around its circumference with small cautery needles by pricking.
Deinde dimitte eam.	Then let it go.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	For it will hasten with the maturation.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	But if you wish to make a hole in it with a cautery, then use a cautery iron of this form.
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	And place it in the middle of Adubelati until it penetrates the skin: and let the cautery iron be from that which follows the infirm person, to relieve the course of purges.
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	¶ On the method of cauterizing in a corroding ulcer.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter 38.
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	A corroding ulcer is not other than a corruption in a moving member, and it corrodes it: just as fire consumes dry wood.
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	If therefore you see a corroding ulcer in a place that can bear cautery with fire, then use many cautery irons, small and large, according to what is suitable for that place where the corroding ulcer is.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	Then cauterize it from all sides until the whole root of the corruption is removed, and nothing remains of it entirely.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	Then leave it for three days, and place on the cauterized areas ground sulfur with oil until all the scabs are removed and all corruption is eliminated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	Then care for it with flesh-generating ointments.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	If therefore you see that after three days the flesh is born with healthy birth, in which there is no corruption, it is good.
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	And if not: then repeat the cauterization on what remains from the corrupted areas.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	And abrading, heal sometimes with sharp medicine.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	For it arises in the place of the cauterization.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	However, the cauterization with fire is faster of healing: and indeed I have already said about its cauterization with sharp medicine in division: take it therefore there when you need it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	§ On the method of cauterizing in warts, and verucae.
Caput LV.	Chapter 50.
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	Frequently it happens in the lower parts of the feet this sickness: and it is a rough, seeping thing which harms the foot.
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	And indeed the cauterization in them is according to two modes: cauterization with fire, and cauterization with hot water.
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	However much with fire is, so that you ignite the cauterization concave like a penfeather: which is made of iron, according to the quantity it contains the claw from every part: and it is thin of the edge.
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	Then place it burning on the claw.
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	Then turn your hand with the cauterization around the claw, until the cauterization reaches the depth of the claw: and leave it for three days, until it begins to emit pus.
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	Then apply plasters to it with soft sulfur, crushed with salt: and leave the plaster on it at night.
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	He will be uprooted from his roots.
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound with a generative flesh ointment until it heals.
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	If they are not converted and often occur on the surface of the body, especially on the hands and feet: then apply heat to them with hot water: and take a needle from the air, or iron, or from the feather of a bird: and place it on the wound, or althelul.
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	Then throw in the needle from hot water with a small amount of quantity: hold your hand and turn it with compression of your hand for a moment, so that the edge of the needle is pressed into the root of the wound, and the hot water finds a way to the depth, to the root of the wound: and wait for the weak one for a moment on the stinging of hot water for an hour.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	Then let him go, for the wound is healed with its roots.
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	So do with them one after another, until you come upon all who are in the body.
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	Then care for them after they are uprooted, with what generates flesh from ointments.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	On the method of cauterizing in Tremor.
Caput LVI.	Chapter 66.
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	When it happens to someone Tremor from cold in the nerve, or from quartan fever, or from another: then it is necessary to cauterize him with four or five cauteries on the spinous processes of the back, and between every spinal process cauterize, and in his chest cauterize, and over his stomach cauterize.
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	For Tremor is quiet with the cauterization of oil, and hastens the health of the cold sickness.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	On the method of cauterizing Albathir.
Caput LVII.	Chapter LVII.
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	Sometimes foul-smelling boils, known as abscesses, form in the body from corrupted coarse matter.
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	Therefore, when they first appear, they must be cauterized over the entire head of the boil with a fine cautery and a stick of myrtle, whose end is burned with fire.
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	Or with the root of a long-stemmed Aristolochia.
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	Or with a round cautery.
Et quandoque cauterizantur ademenul, in principio expulsionis suae secundum hunc modum: et non augentur: et disrumpitur superfluitas faciens eos, et sanatur ex eis.	And sometimes they are cauterized a little at the beginning of their expulsion in this way: and they do not increase: and the excess is broken, which causes them, and they are healed from them.
