Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	However, it must be done after evacuation with venesection.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	About the method of cauterizing in the flow of blood from an artery into a wound.
Caput LVIII.	Chapter LVIII.
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	Many times it happens that the flow of blood from an artery cut at a wound, which occurs outside, or at the incision of an abscess, or a cauterized member, and similar to them, is difficult to remove.
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	Therefore, when it happens to someone, then hurry with your hand to the opening of the artery, and put your finger on top of it: and press it much, until the blood is held back under your finger, and nothing comes out of it.
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Then put in the fire a small and many cautery irons: and blow on them, until they are heated greatly.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then take from them one, or a few, or many, according to the wound and the place where the artery is broken, and put the cautery on the vein after you remove your finger quickly: and hold the cautery until the blood is cut off.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	If the thorn is expelled from the opening of the artery and the hot iron is extinguished, then take another hot iron quickly, prepared from the irons that are in the fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Therefore do not cease to do this with one after another, until the blood stops flowing.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	And beware, lest you burn the nerves which are there, and a new evil falls upon the weak one.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And know that when blood flows from the artery, then it is not possible to remove it: especially when the artery is large, unless with one of four methods.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or with a hot iron, as we have said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or with extraction when it is not extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is extracted, the ends of it contract, and the blood is cut off.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or it is tied with a strong ligature.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or they place on it remedies of its property, which is to cut off the blood and bind it with a decent compression.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	But whoever administers its division with a ligature and binding with a cloth, and position of things that burn and similar, does not give it completely, unless rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	But if this happens to someone and there is no physician present nor medicine: then begin with the position of the index finger over the opening of the vein itself, as we have told, and bind it greatly, until the blood is stopped from the upper part of the wound and above the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And the finger is not removed, above it with cold water of great cold always, until the blood freezes, and swells, and is cut off.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	And meanwhile he considers in it what is needed from the hot iron, or from the medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	Part One Conclusion.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	Book of Surgery by Albucasis, Part Two.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	On Incision, Puncture, and Phlebotomy in Wounds, and Similar Matters.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	As we have said in the first chapter, all pain that is suitable for the use of a cauterizer and burning medicine, its causes, reasons, and instruments, and forms of cauterization.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I placed chapters from head to toe.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And I proceed in this chapter the same way: that it may bring relief to the one seeking what has been sought.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin that, you must learn, my son, what is in this chapter from the terror that is in the first chapter on cauterization.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	And for that reason, there must be greater caution in it, because in the operation that is in this chapter, very often fainting occurs with blood, with which life stands at the opening of the vein, or incision over an abscess, or opening of the exit, or cure of the wound, or extraction of the arrow, or incision on a stone, and those similar: from all of which, trembling, fear, and death often fall in many of them.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I advise you, not to fall upon you that in which there is hesitation, for sometimes such men with their ways of weaknesses come to you in this art.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	For from them is one who is angry with his pain, and is light in him for death: because of the vehemence of which he found from his weakness and length of his malice.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And with pain is from fear that means death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And from them is he who gives his flute to you, and gives you with it, hoping for health, and his illness is destructive.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	Therefore it is not necessary to agree with him who comes to you from them, whose manner is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	And let your caution be more urgent than his desire and your greed.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	And do not presume upon anything from him unless after a certain knowledge that confirms to you that the succession of that to which he arrives is praiseworthy.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And use them in the treatment of all your sick, for diagnosis and indication of that to which it is properly healthful.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	For in him you have help for the acquisition of fame and glory, and memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God inspire you, O son, his understanding, and not take from you direction and inspiration: for that is in his hand.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And I indeed ordained this Chapter by distinguishing it into chapters, according to what preceded in the chapter of cauterization, from the forehead to the feet: so that you may be relieved of what you seek from him, and what you need.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	¶ On the treatment of water that gathers in the heads of children.
Caput I.	Chapter 1.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	You should know that this weakness often occurs to children at birth: or when the midwife compresses the head of the child without gentleness.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And also it happens even from a hidden cause which is not known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	And I indeed have not seen this weakness in other than in children: and to all whom I saw from them it was urgent for death: therefore it seemed to me to leave the operation in that.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	I myself have seen a child whose head was filled with water, and his head was celebrated every day until he could not sit on himself due to the size of his head, and the moisture increased until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	This moisture, however, either accumulates between the skin and the bone, or under the bones above the skull.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And the operation in that case, if the moisture is between the skin and the bone and it is a small abscess, then it is necessary to make a cut in the middle of the head, one in width, and the length of the cut should be about two knots, until the moisture runs out.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	This is the shape of the lancet.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	If however the moisture is more increased and the abscess is larger, then place these two cuts according to this form.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	And if the moisture is under the bone, and the sign of it is that you see the edges of the head open from all sides, and the water is pressed when you press it with your hand to the insides, and does not hide itself from you, then it is necessary to make three cuts in the middle of the head, according to this method.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after the incision, extract all the moisture.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then bind the cuts with cloth and cotton.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then poultice it from above with wine and oil until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then dissolve the ligament, and care for the wound with bandages, ointment.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not dismiss binding the head with equality.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	And feed the sick person with every dry food of little moisture, until the limb is strengthened and healed.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	And another method of incision is to consider where the size of the abscess appears and the collection of water.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	For sometimes there is more in the back, or on the forehead, or on the right side, or on the left side.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	Therefore approach with an incision where you see the abscess and its filling with water, and cut it according to what is possible for you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	And observe, so that you do not cut the artery, and the blood flows out, and the sick person dies from that flow with the evacuation of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	¶ On the incision of the arteries which are after the ears.
Caput II.	Chapter 2.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When catarrh occurs to someone's eyes, or chest, and it is not cured by medical treatment: then the last cure in that case is the incision of these two arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	Therefore when you want to incise them, so that the sick person may recover his head.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then rub the place with a rough cloth, so that the arteries appear.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then the sick person ties his neck with any of his cloths.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then consider where the pulse is.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And the locations of both are locations which are after the ears depressed: and it is rarely hidden, unless in some men.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then signs with the cautery on both: and cut both with a narrow knife on either side, with the incision going to the bone: and let that be done through the width of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if you want, insert a narrow knife under the artery, and cut it to the upper part with the incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And let the length of the incision be as two fingers joined together.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when the pulse is cut, the blood flows out in a small amount, which jumps to the insides frequently.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	If, however, the artery does not appear to the senses, then it is necessary to measure from the ear the distance of three fingers.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then mark with the cautery and probe until you reach the bone.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And that which should be expelled from the blood is six unciae and perhaps you may expel more or less from it.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	All of that according to the quantity which appears to you from the weakness and fullness of its artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then consider the wound.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	Then if there remains from the bone any flesh, then cut that, so that it does not become a hot abscess: then bind the wound with lint from cloth.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it is healed.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	¶ On the extraction of arteries which are in the temples.
Caput III.	Chapter 3.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When it happens to a man that he has ancient hemicrania, or sharp cataracts due to acrimonious humors, and heat in the temples, or old bile, strong, and similar to those: and he is treated with the methods of medical cure, and does not bear it: then we have experienced these pains in extraction of arteries from the temples, or cauterization of them, as we have narrated.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the method of operation in their extraction is, that the weak hair which are in the temples be shaved, and he stretch to the artery appearing in the temple.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	For indeed it is shown to you from its pulse, and rarely is hidden except in a few men, or by great cold.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	But if it is hidden from you, then he bind his weak head with any of his cloths: then rub the place with a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Or apply warm water to the wound until it appears manifest to you.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take a small needle, which I previously shaped.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then scrape away the skin with it, with ease, until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then push the hook into it, and pull it out towards the top, until you have removed it from the skin, and make it recede from the garments that are underneath it from all sides.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If however the artery is delicate: then cover it with the tip of the hook.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then cut from that part according to the quantity by which their ends lengthen and contract, and do not let any blood flow.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it is not cut, and if it is not severed, the blood will not rise at all.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then wash out from the blood six ounces, up to three.
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	But if the artery is large: then it is necessary to ligate it in two places with double silk thread, strong silk thread, or with catgut, so that it does not rush towards putrefaction before the consolidation of the wound, and let any blood flow.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut away the excess, which is between the two ligatures.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do this at that hour, or after another hour.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if you wish, cauterize it with a cautery up to the bone, with a cautery knife: until their ends are cut off, and it remains in the place of that work.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	And it is better work, unless if he is weak and has a fever, or a heated constitution.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	Because the cautery is from those things which help to end moisture.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore it is a better bandage.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And after the extraction of the arteries, it is necessary to fill the place with old dough: and they should be placed on top of it, well-made felt.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after the solution, it should be treated with dry medicines, which make flesh grow, and with liniments, until it heals.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If, however, while you are working, bleeding occurs from the artery, then hurry to cut it off with a cauterizer, or fill the place with zeugit: and tighten your hand until the blood is cut off.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	If there is nothing present for you, then place your finger on the place until the blood congeals.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And rub the place with hot water, until the sharpness subsides, and it is tied as it should be.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	Because it is lighter and easier to extract the artery, it is that with a cauterizer having two knives: let the sharpness of the two knives be like alum.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	However, they are much less sharp than two knives.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	Because if they are as sharp as two knives, each frost hurries: and they do not cut the flesh with speed.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	Since there is a little thickness in them, the heat of the fire is held in them, and the flesh is cut quickly: therefore this work is better for all operations, lighter, and easier.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And there should be a space that is the thickness of a finger between the two knives, after you mark two places with encaustic: and place both hot ones very near, until they reach the bone, and cut the vein in two places: so that it is lengthened between its ends.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	They are not solidified completely with this cauterizing agent.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	And this is the shape of the cauterizing instrument.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	About the care of the course of frequent, sharp tears from the eyes.
Caput IIII.	Chapter 4.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When tears are frequent and their course is from the eyes, which are above the outside of the skull: and no remedy of medicine is applied to them with other medicines, and you see the face of the sick already red, and feels walking in front of him, like the walk of ants: and his eyes are thinned, wet, so that already the hair on their pores is worn out with wear: and his eyelids are heated by the sharpness of the tears: then the ancients were in need of this cure, and called it a remedy, with the Sword.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	And you should order the sick to shave the hairs that are on his forehead.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then cut three fissures evenly spaced according to the length of the forehead: and the length of the fissure is about two fingers, and the fissure one is evenly spaced from the length of the nose in the middle of the forehead, and the second according to the length of the arm slightly, and the third on the other side: and beware of the incision of the arteries that are on both sides: and extend your hand away from the continuity of the two jaws, and all the quantity of the incision is three fingers together: and it should be a piece of sponge prepared, or dry cloth with which you dry the blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then insert a small spatula of two sharp ends, whose following is this form.
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the incision that is from the temporal side, to the second incision: and scrape with it all the skin that is between two incisions, with the scar, which is on the bone.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then also do that from the middle incision up to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then extract this space, and insert again the second incision another tool, which is called a sharp knife, smooth on one side, not sharp on the other.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And place its sharp side towards the flesh with the skin, and its smooth side towards the mouth: and push it until it reaches the middle cut: and cut off with it all the vessels that descend from the head to the eyes: except that the incision continues until what appears of the skin.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then do that in the middle cut up to another cut.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And after it has flowed out an equal amount of blood, press the places from clots of coagulated blood.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then place on every cut a piece of old cooked linen, and place above them cloths soaked in wine, or oil, or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And see that no hot abscess occur.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	And on the third day dissolve the ligament, and administer a lot of infusion with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then care for it with basilicon ointment, and with the other things by which wounds are cured: until it is healed.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	¶ On the care of sharp tears and catarrh from the eyes from inside the head.
Caput V.	Head V.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When catarrh occurs to someone sharp, acute, and frequent: and you see his eyes weakened, small, and already weakened is their aspect: and the eyelids are ulcerated, and they fall off from them, and in the deep of the head is sharp pain, wounding, and following sneezing: then take from these accidents that those matters, and catarrh do not come, unless from many vines.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	The best cure for them is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	And you should command the sick person to shave their forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then make one incision in the middle of their forehead, or another slightly longer across its width, and begin from the left temple to the right temple: and the incision should reach the bone: and keep your hand away from the moving temples during chewing: until the bone is exposed: and dry all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate between the two lips of the incision with an old knife, or with linen strips.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then tie above with swabs: and soak the swabs with wine and oil, so that no heat abscess forms.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you cure it, and see that the heat abscess is beginning to diminish: then you must scrape the bone, until flesh begins to grow in it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then care for it with a dry diet that promotes the growth of flesh: as if you take two parts of wheat flour and four parts of pitch: and prepare an ointment from them, and administer it to the birth of flesh in these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	§ On the care of what falls into the Ear.
Caput VI.	Chapter 6.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	Everything that falls into the ear is one of four kinds: either a mineral stone, or a similar stone, such as iron and lead: or it is a plant, such as peas and beans: or it is a fluid, such as water, and vinegar, and similar things: or some animal.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When therefore a stone, or kind of stone, falls into the ear from those which do not add or grow in the ear, expose the ear alone: if you then see the stone, then pour something from broken oil, or saffron, into the ear.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then administer extraction of it, and make him sneeze with the conditioned powder, and wipe the nose upon the approach of sneezing, after you have placed in the circumference of the ear fragments of cloth or wool, and extend the ear towards the upper part.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	For often it exits with this care.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	But if it does not exit, then administer extraction of it with Gesti, that is, Subtle Powder: whose form is this.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	Therefore if it exits with Gesti, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then administer extraction of it with a blind hook of few duplicates.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	Therefore if it does not exit through that, then make a cannula from air, and insert the end of the cannula into the ear canal far, and wipe what is in the circumference of the cannula with softened cera and oil, so that there is no wind way except through the cannula: then extract with your strong attraction.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	For often it exits with what we have mentioned.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	But if it does not exit this way: then take from helkalimbat, or from uisco, that is, prepared glue with which birds are caught, a small amount: and place it at the end of the radius after you have wrapped it properly over it: then insert it into the ear canal with ease, after you have dried the ear from moisture.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	Therefore if it does not exit with all that we have mentioned, then hasten to cut it before an abscess of hot pus, or spasm occurs.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	And the method of cutting is, that you use a lancet on the weak one in the first in the cefalica: and extract from him according to the measure of its power from blood.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then make the weak one sit between your hands, and turn his ear towards the upper part, and cut a small fissure in the root of the ear at the fat of him in the place depressed by himself: and let the fissure be of lunar shape, until you reach the stone: then remove it with what is possible from your instruments.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then quickly cut a wound from your hour with diligence, and care for it until it heals.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	If something falling into your ear is from one of the grains that grow and swell: then administer its removal.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	But if it does not obey you at the end, then take a thin, delicate lance in this shape.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And administer with it the cutting of that kind from the grains that fall into the ear, and do not do it when you think that that grain is already moistened by the steam of the ear, until you put many fragments: then extract them with hooks, or with a delicate forceps, or with suction, as we said, for its removal is relieved.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	But in the water that enters the ear, it is necessary to use a weak sneeze with it first: and now it has filled its own ear with a little old boil: and it is lying on that ear, in which is the water.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If therefore it goes out through that, it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if not: then take many stones, according to the length of the finger, thin, gentle, and heat them with fire for a while, and let the weak one insert one of them into the hole of his ear: and salt on one foot of it, and strike with another stone on the stone that is in the ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	Therefore do not stop doing it with the stone and the stone, until all the water goes out.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And now the water goes out so that you take one from the parpyro, or from the junco, and insert one end of it into the ear: and light the other end with fire, until it is burned very much.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then repeat the junco another, and do it many times, until all the water goes out: and extract it with a cannula according to what was prescribed in the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	In the extraction of animals that enter into it, if it is small, like a flea or something similar, care for it as I mentioned in division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if it is a large body that appears to the senses: then administer its extraction with forceps and hooks, and its matter is easier than all that are held in the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	In the extraction of worms generated in the ear, when you care for it with what we mentioned in division and in the treatment of distillations, and your cure does not join: then you must look at the ear in the sunlight.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	Therefore if something appears there from the worms, then extract it with forceps or with fine hooks.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	But if nothing appears there, then take a cannula, of which this is its form, narrow at the bottom, wide at the top: and insert its thin end into the ear according to the amount that an infirm person can tolerate: then suck with it strong suction.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Do this many times, until all the worms come out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	But if they do not obey you to the end, then wrap a bandage around the cannula with clay, as I said in the stone.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	If they do not come out with it, then administer the distillations that the ancients have already known in the infestation of worms: and you will find it in the treatment of distillations.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And let your outpouring be like the one you pour out oil and medicines into the ear with this instrument, of which its form is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	Just as you see make it from silver, or from brass, narrow at the bottom, in which there is a small hole, wide at the top.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	Therefore let the pushing part that is in the hollow of the cannula be made from brass properly.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	If you wish, take the needle and wrap it in a piece of cotton, wrapping it properly: then apply oil, or honey, or whatever you wish from these remedies into the needle: let it be in the ear: then insert the needle with the cotton on top, and express it gently by your hand compression until the oil is pushed into the concavity of the ear, and he feels it inside: and what is poured into the ear should already be warmed slightly with fire: and beware that there is nothing that distills into it very cold, for remedies do not tolerate this.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	On the care of the accidental affection of the Ear.
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	Sometimes certain children come out from the wombs of their mothers not perforated.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And now it also happens to some people that the affection of the ear occurs in the opening of the ear from a wound, or flesh born in it.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this affection of the ear sometimes occurs in the deep opening of the ear, which does not follow sight: and sometimes it happens to the outer openings a little, and follows sight.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	Therefore those which happen in the deep ear, and which does not include sight, is difficult to cure in many positions.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And in that which follows sight, it is necessary to place the ear of the sick person in the sun, and look at it: then if you see the affection appearing, open it with a narrow sharp needle, whose form is as follows, which follows, its end is in which there is a small width, whose part is sharp: and the rest of the needle is two-edged: so that it does not hurt the ear.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If therefore the affection is born from flesh in the opening of the ear: then hold it with a narrow sharp knife, and cut it with great force, until all the flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	If the wax is deep in the ear, then take a thin, soft, and warm radulum, heat it slightly with fire, and then put it into the ear canal.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If you feel the wax with it that is found in the ear of an unhealthy person with severity, try to open it with ease: and beware, do not wound the nerves of the ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then put linum in the ear according to the quantity of the width of the hole you cleaned with Egyptian ointment: do this for several days until you are secure about the consolidation of the wound.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take linum, and pour it into rosewater, and sprinkle powdered zeig on top of it, and use it.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	If you see the ear is already abscessing, then it is necessary to remove the linum, and let it be with another linen cloth that you cleaned with a cerate made with rose oil, until the abscess becomes warm: then care for it until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	But if bloodletting occurs, then soak a sponge or cloth in cold water, and put it on the ear: and use the rest of the cure that stops the predicted bleeding in the treatment of distillations.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	On the care of the eyelids of Althelia.
Caput VIII.	Chapter 8.
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	These Althelia who occur in the eyelids of the eye, sometimes are moist, and sometimes are dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	Therefore it is necessary to hold them with tweezers: or with an uncinus, and cut them with a small knife from their roots.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then put powdered zeig on the places.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	But if blood flows from them, then cauterize them with a thin lens-shaped cauterizer.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	And it is better to cauterize them after the incision.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	For often they return when something remains from their roots.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots are burned and do not return.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	About the care of the eyelids of the eye.
Caput IX.	Chapter 9.
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	Often something similar to chilblain occurs in the eyelids due to its strength and hardness, and because of this it is called Grando: and it is an aggregation of thick moisture on the upper eyelid and lower eyelid.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	Therefore the operation in them is that you should consider whether it is chilblain proceeding from that which appears on the eyelid, and move to every part, and its matter is easy.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Therefore find a cut above it in width.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then scrape it off from every part with ease until it becomes soft.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then suspend it with a needle, and cut it off.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	But if the cut of it is not prepared for you unless after you penetrate the eyelid with the incision a little, then it harms the weak one in some place.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	But if the cut is large: then gather it with suture and care for it until it becomes healthy.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if it is small, harm will not come to you from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	For ointment restores it and covers it.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if chilblain is declining towards the inside of the ear against the inner surface, then turn the eyelid and suspend the chilblain with a needle: besides which you need incision and press it from every part.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	But if the eyelid is stretched by incision, it does not harm it in some place.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then wash the eye after the incision of the granite, with salty water: and care for the place with it that fleshs, until the sick one heals.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	On the care of Axiromath eyelids.
Caput X.	Chapter X.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	Axirnath is a fat that is generated in the upper eyelid skins: and indeed it often happens to children: and this one does indeed blind their eyes, and they are affected with cataracts in the morning, and they cannot see the sunlight, because their tears rush to them, and because of this you see them always lying on their faces, and they sleep on them, and their eyelids are under wet arches, which have already been covered by inflation: indeed the eminence of Axirnath appears to the eye, and when you press the place with your fingers, you feel Axirnath between them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the method of its operation is, that the sick one puts his head on your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take a linen cloth and prepare linseed in it, and make from it a circle according to the amount that contains Axirnath from all parts.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then put him on it, and press with your fingers from all parts, so that Axirnath is gathered in the middle of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then find in the middle of its moisture with a sharp needle making incisions along the width, and let there not be an incision greater than that which is made in bloodletting in the deep.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Or it is necessary to make an incision in the whole skin, until you reach Axirnath, for indeed Axirnath proceeds from many arrangements through the incision according to the shape of a slice of white fat.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Then extract it with the cloth that you have placed between your fingers to the outsides: and you turn your hand to the right and left, until it is spread: and beware, do not add in the incision, so that it does not reach with the sharp needle to the eye, and you harm him.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	If, however, Achirnath does not appear to you at the beginning of the incision, you will add a little with ease into the incision until Achirnath proceeds.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then extract it, as we said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Then dip the cloths in vinegar and water, and place them on the spot, and bind it with bandages.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And there are some who apply salt to it, and place it in the hollow of the incision, so that what remains from that moisture is melted.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	But if an abscess occurs in that hot spot, then care for it with soothing plasters until it heals.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	¶ On the ways of Ataxmir's eye, that is, when the eyelid becomes soft and the eye becomes loosed, so that it weeps as it should not.
Caput XI.	Chapter 11.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When additional hairs are born in the eyelids beyond their natural course under the hairs, and they become ancient: then they harm the eye, and cause afflictions, such as frequent tears, and softening of the eyelids, and the white of the eye, until that becomes the cause of destruction of the eye.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	And indeed, Ataxmir's eye is cured according to four ways.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or by cauterization with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with sharp medicine, as was previously mentioned in the chapter on cauterization.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Or it is cured by incision and sutures.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or by cannula, as I will say.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	It is necessary to place the head of the sick person in your lap.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then turn the eyelid of the eye with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If he turns over, it is good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if not: insert the needle into the one where there is a thread from the lower part of the eyelid, and make the needle penetrate with the thread above, and let it be near the hairs, that is, near the margin of the eyelid where the hairs grow: and pull the thread upwards with the eyelid, and turn it with a spoon.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then find in the inner part of the eyelid under the added hairs with a small spatula reaching from the larger lacrimal canal up to the smaller lacrimal canal.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then extract the thread, and place under the eyelid a small piece of charcoal or cloth: then mark on the eyelid with a hot iron, which is like the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	However, it must be made into a shape according to the size and elevation of the eyelid: for it is already varied among men.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	For there are those who need that a large amount of it should be incised from the eyelid according to the amount which is softened from the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then with a small spatula find above two lines which you marked, and begin from the larger lacrimal canal up to the smaller lacrimal canal, and let there be a fissure near the natural hairs, like the size of a ray.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then insert a hook into one of the two angles of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then scrape it all off.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then gather with a stitch two lips, with a needle and fine woolen thread: and wipe off the blood, and make that which superfluously flows from the threads on top of two eyebrows, with some things concealing it, if you want to make that: and if not, do not care.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then let go of the suture and thread for three days, or four; afterwards care for that.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, let go of the wound without suture, and care for it along with that which dries and constricts.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid is raised at the marking of the wound and its congregation, but a better one is to come.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	This method of healing was taught by the ancients Ataxmir.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	However, there is worry over the weak one, and it is from good operation, and there is not in it fear.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And another method is in Ataxmir also: and it is, to mark the signs above the eyelid, which is like the figure of a myrtle leaf, as we have narrated.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then raise the eyelid with three separate or aggregated needles, according to this following form, then cut what is superfluous with small scissors, according to this form, with equality of cutting.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	But if it is not possible for you to hold the needle, and it is not equal: then take an awl in which there is thread, and insert it in the middle of the figure: and insert the thread another near the lacrimal greater, and the thread near the lacrimal less: and gather the thread with equality between your fingers.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then raise your hand evenly: and raise the skin above which is marked cloth, as we have narrated.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then gather two wound lips with suture: and care for it, until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	But if indeed abscess happens at your incision, or your wound: squeeze the abscess with charred, and with such like, from ointments suppressing.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And sometimes it happens to the eyelids also, that their hairs turn.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	Therefore, you should use what we mentioned in the incision, but the suture on both sides is more artificial.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	About the care of Ataxmir with dogs.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	And it is, to turn back the eyelid and cut open the incision that is inside, as I have mentioned.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then make two splints, or two thin pieces of wood: their length should be according to the length of the eyelid, and their width should be less than the width of a fingernail: and you have already cut at the ends of each from both sides where you hold the threads.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then gather each of them with thinness on top of what is excessive from the eyelid of the eye, and tie two splints from both sides with a strong knot, and let it be for several days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	For the skin will die, and blacken, and rot, until it falls off by itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	If therefore it is delayed, then cut it with forceps.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When therefore it is consolidated, elevate the eyelid: and do not prick the hairs.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	And this is the shape of two splints, which you will make according to this figure, and in length and width.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	About raising hairs that prick in the eye with a needle.
Caput XII.	Chapter 12.
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The operation in that is, to take a thin needle, and insert it into the hair with a thin silk thread, gentle.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then gather its ends, and tie both with a thin knot very tightly: and the length of the threads should be one finger.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then make another thin thread under it in a short, and tie its ends if you wish.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then place the patient's head in your lap, and let it be near the sun so that the operation can be clearly seen: for this is a delicate or minor operation.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then introduce the probe with a curved needle into the root of the eyelid, and make it penetrate the eyelid quickly until you remove it from above with a natural spica.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then pull the needle up to the curved needle: and introduce the needle into the curved needle: if it is one, or two, or three, not more.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then pull your hand with it until the needle exits the eyelid with the curved needle and the natural spica.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	But if the curved needle is drawn out, and the needle does not exit with it: pull the curved needle downwards with the thread that you have made in it, until the curved needle exits from the upper opening, and see it with the sight of the eye: for then draw out the curved needle and the thread: and remove both, and close the eye: and let him be closed for two days or three, until the needle sticks in its place, and flesh grows over it.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	But if the needle is short, then associate it with a long needle from the natural needles, and elevate it with it: or let him be left until it lengthens after some time, and then elevate it.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	¶ On the care of Alexander that happens in the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When this Alexander's disease happens to the eye, it is called Leprosy.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And this Alexander's disease is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	Therefore it becomes accidental from the consolidation of the wound, or cutting, or cauterization, and similar to those.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	The method of operation for this is as follows: you should find the consolidation and separate her lips, and place a linen cloth between them, and bind it up until she heals.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And you should not use things in her treatment that dry and constrict: for if you do this, the Alexander's plaster will return worse than before. Instead, use things that soften, such as fenugreek, and embrocate with water in which althea has been boiled, linseed oil, and Dyaquilon ointment, which has been melted with some oil: and wrap up the linen cloth with this, and take care of her.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	Your treasure for healing is to try by all means to prevent it from becoming consolidated according to its original form.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	Indeed, this operation that we mentioned is nothing but a certain correction of the Alexander's plaster, so that it does not return to its original form at all.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	¶ About the care of the Alexander's plaster that is made on the lower eyelid, and there is a wrinkle or contraction upwards towards the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 14.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This Alexander's plaster that is made below is what is truly called the Alexander's plaster.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	And it is both natural and accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	And the accidental one is made from a wound, or a tear, or a cauterization, and similar things.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	The method of operation for this is as follows: you should take an awl, in which there is a double thread, and stain it with flesh, and make it penetrate from the left lachrymal to the right, until the thread reaches both ends of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then extend the flesh upwards with the awl, and cut it with a broad-bladed knife.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If the figure of the eyelid returns as it should, it is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	And if not, take the probe, and place it in the fissure, and turn the eyelid with it: and make two fissures on the inner side of the eyelid, and let the ends of the two fissures be from two angles of the incision, until they meet and form an angle: until when they gather, this figure is formed, and it is the Greek letter laud.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then remove that flesh by the amount that is the sharp side of its width, from that which follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then gather the separated parts: sew it with a wool thread.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then care for them with that which we said, with softening medicines and liniments, until they are healed.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if Alexander occurs from the fissure, and the suture, or with a cautery: then it is necessary to make the fissure flat under the eyelashes, even as it preceded.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate between two lips with liniment, as we said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And the main word of speech on the care of Alexander, when it is above, or below, is that it should operate in it, according to how it is prepared from the form of Alexander.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	For indeed it is of many diverse forms: and the skillful artist prepares his ingenuity with whatever way is possible to him, until he makes it return to the natural form, or near to it, and himself the sick man, according to what suits him from the operation and instruments in many dispositions.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	¶ On the adherence of the eyelid of the eye with the conjunctiva, or the cornea.
Caput XV.	Chapter XV.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	Sometimes this consolidation happens to many people, so that the upper eyelid is consolidated with the whites of the eye and prevents it from performing its natural operations.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	Therefore you must insert the tip of the radius under the eyelid and raise it up: or extend it with a blunt hook, then cut the adhesion with a thin, sharp spatula, which is not sharp with the incision of the spatula, but rather blunt for a moment: so that the weak one does not suffer from the operation, and the spatula is removed, and it does not injure the eye with its sharpness: and your incision is as if you were excoriating that adhesion with ease, until when the eyelid returns to its natural form, and the adhesion is completely healed.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Then pour salt water into the eye, with clean water washing it: or sprinkle it in the eye from a sharp-edged vessel made of tin, dissolved in water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate between the eyelid and the eye with a soft linen cloth: and place on the eye wool soaked with albumin: and after three days use the sharp-edged vessel, and with solidifying agents, until it is healed.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	¶ On the incision of the nail and prominence of flesh of tears.
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	Know that the nail is in two ways.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	Either it is nervous: and it is similar to a sharp-edged vessel, thin.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is not nervous, similar to frozen moisture of white: which when it touches the flesh of iron, or you try to take it with a hook, it is cut off, and does not stick in it the hook.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	And both species do not begin, except from the greater tear duct, until it gradually approaches, until it covers the eye, and prevents light, and movement of the eye.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	The method of operation for this incision is: place your infirm head in my lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open his eyes and raise his eyelid with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Then gather the claw with a small fold of skin and extend it to the upper part.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then take a needle and insert a small hair from a horse, or a goose, into it: let the thread be strong, and double the tip of the needle slightly, and fix it in the middle of the claw; and pierce it with the needle, and tie it with the thread, and extend it to the upper part: and scrape the side of the claw that follows the pupil, as if you were pulling it with the hair up to the end of its tail.
