But if this instrument is not present to you, then take a cannula, and place in its extremity a piece of cork: so that the mouth of the sick person is not burned: for the cork prevents the vapor from burning the mouth: and this is from good treatment with health.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	About the extraction of thorns, and bones from the mouth.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter 38.
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Many things stick in the throat, such as a fish bone, or another thing.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	Therefore, you should remove what is visible on top of what falls under the view, after placing your tongue with the instrument facing the sun, and it is declared to you that it is in the throat.
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And what does not appear to you and is hidden in the throat, you should make a weak emetic before the food is digested in the stomach.
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	Perhaps the attached thing will come out through vomiting.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Or the weak person will swallow a piece of bread, or the root of lettuce, or a dry crust of bread: or he will receive a piece of sponge sea, and tie it with a thread, then swallow it.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	When therefore it has reached the place where the bones, or the bone, are, and is removed, then it comes out.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	If therefore it does not come out with what we said: then use the tool from lead according to this form.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	Let it be thicker than the Radius a little, and at the end of it there is a narrowness, which he can insert into his throat with ease: and he himself has his head raised up.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And beware of touching his epiglottis, so that it does not happen to him cough, and he pushes with it the bone, or the fish bone, or inserts it himself with his hand.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	But what the weak person inserts, this is better: because of his knowledge of the place of the attached thing: and he pushes down, or he draws his hand with the instrument upwards, all that according to the quantity which is prepared for him, until it comes out.
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	¶ Of the extraction of a leech.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter 39.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When treating a bleeding wound with the method I mentioned in the division of treatment with medicines, and it does not stop, then consider placing the injured person in front of the sun, or near the sun after applying the instrument I told you about to their tongue.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If therefore your sight falls upon the bleeding wound, remove it with a small spoon, or with a fine instrument gently.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	If it is not possible with those, then take a hollow needle and insert it into the throat of the injured person until near the throat: then insert the heated iron into the hollow of the needle with fire.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do this frequently: and let the injured person avoid all water for the whole day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then let him receive a full glass of cold water and open his mouth in it: and cover his mouth with it, and not swallow any from it: and move the water one hour after another with his hand.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	For the bleeding wound immediately when it feels the water falls.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	But if it does not leave with what we told you, then smoke the injured person with cimices, or with asafetida with the instrument I told you about in the smoking of the wound.
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do this frequently, for it will fall itself.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the method of operation in smoking is, that you take a pot in which there are live prunes with fire: and the pot is covered with a cover, in which there is a hole: and the instrument is placed in this hole at its end.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then throw the smoking, and let him place his mouth in the end of the needle, and close his mouth, so that the smoking does not escape, until you know that the smoking has reached the bleeding wound.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the bloodletting will immediately fall.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	But if it does not fall, then repeat the fumigation many times.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And the weak one will bear thirst, and eat salted food, and ointments, and not drink water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	Therefore it is necessary that he go out with this regimen.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the form of the instrument with which bloodletting is removed from the throat, when it falls on it.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is similar to forceps, as you see: except that it has this curve which enters the throat.
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its end is similar to the beak of a bird called a stork, which has a roughness of a file: when it grasps something, it does not let it go at all.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	Concerning the opening of pustules, and their cutting, and care in general.
Caput XL.	Chapter 40.
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	Pustules are of many species, of many modes, according to which the remembrance comes of them, namely one and one in this book: and they are diverse in their piercing, and cutting of them from two ways.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	Of which one is from the species of pustules in itself, and because it contains from moistures.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And the second mode is because of the places, in which it happens from the body.
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	Because the pustule happening in the head, is other from the pustule happening in the anus: and the pustule happening in a fleshy place, is other from the pustule happening in the joints: and to each of them is its own judgment from the operation.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And from the pustules are those which it is not necessary that they be pierced, unless after the maturation of the pus in them, and its completion: and from them are those which it is necessary that they be pierced, while they are raw, and not mature according to the completion.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	As abscesses which are near the joints.
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	Because an abscess, when it occurs near a joint, and is allowed to continue, may cause the surrounding tissue to putrefy, possibly corrupting the ligaments or nerves of that joint: therefore, this is a closer cause of contraction of that limb.
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or it is an abscess in a principal limb: for if you delay the incision of it until it ripens, it will harm either him or through that principal limb.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	Or it is near the anus, so pierce it immaturely: and it is not necessary to pierce, a raw abscess, not complete digestion, unless it is near the anus, so that it does not putrefy deeply, and extend to the interior of the anus, and become a fistula, or become in the end that does not heal.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	You should know the time of incision for abscesses that have ripened according to their completion: and it is at the cessation of pain, remission of fever, and diminution of redness, pulse, and sharpness of headache in abscesses: and other signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	And you should do the same incision in the lower part of the abscesses, and more prominent swelling: and the incision should be longitudinal in the length of the body, if the abscesses are in the parts of the hands and feet, and the places of the backs, and chords, and nerves, and arteries, and finally in all equal places where there is no reflection.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	But in those that reflect, go with the incision according to that limb.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	But when the abscess is in fleshy places: then it is better to let go the incision of it until its digestion is confirmed, as we said according to completion.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	For if you pierce it before that, the course of the virus will be prolonged from it, and there are many wounds and filthiness, and perhaps its lips become hardened and its depth.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And some abscesses are pierced according to the width of the body at need: or according to that where the member needs it.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And it is necessary for the administrator in small abscesses to make a small incision, and in large abscesses to make a wide incision: or many cuts according to the likeness of the size of the abscesses.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And there are from abscesses, in which it is necessary for the skin to be hollowed out: and it is incised when already it is like a piece of cloth, and it has been made at the end, which is already dead: such as that which happens in many, so that they doubt, and in buboes.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And from them are those which are cut with a cut having three angles.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And from it is that which is incised as the figure of a myrtle leaf.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Such as an abscess in the groin.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And from them are those in which the administration of a round cut and a crescent-shaped cut is given: and similar to them from the cuts.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	Indeed, that which has no head, such as are the mild abscesses on the surface, it is necessary for you to pierce it with a shallow incision, or a flat one only.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And it is necessary when the abscess is large, and has already collected much pus, and you pierce it, so that you do not rush and remove all the pus at once in that hour: indeed, remove a part of it from it.
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then leave the abscess alone until another day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then remove something from the pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this many times according to the gradation until it comes out, especially if the patient is weak or feeble, a pregnant woman, a small child, an old man, or a decrepit person: for the animal spirit often dissolves with the excretion of pus, and perhaps the weak one dies, and you will not notice it.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore, be very careful about this chapter.
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after your incision, by which you are piercing these abscesses, it is necessary to clean the wound: and consider.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If therefore the wound is small or flat, then apply lint from linen, or old cotton.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	And if the abscess is large, and there are many incisions, then you must insert lint into every incision until it reaches the bottom.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	And if you have cut a part of the skin in the abscess, or hollowed it out: then it is necessary to fill it with old cotton, or as when cloth is sewn, or wool is shorn without moisture: and bind it until the third day.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then put it back, and care for it with what is necessary from the ointment, until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	But if blood flows during your operation, then apply cold water and vinegar, after it has been soaked in the cloth: and put it on the place of the blood flow many times.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	But if the blood flow continues, then you must apply the regimen, and treatment, and powders, which I have mentioned in many places of this our book, and from division.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	But if it is in the time of winter, and the place of the abscesses is many nerves: then you must pour the powders with wine, and warm oil: and put them on the places.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is in summer and the wounds are fleshy: then it is necessary to place moist sawdust soaked in water, or with oil, or with wine and oil, and keep everything cold.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until the third day, as we said, then it is necessary to dissolve the abscess, and cleanse it, and administer what is appropriate for its healing until it is healed.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This is therefore the necessary knowledge of universal abscess healing.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	Indeed, according to the method of distinction, I have already said about every abscess, how there is a way to its healing individually by chapters.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	¶ About the incision of an abscess that occurs on the scalp.
Caput XLI.	Chapter 41.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Small abscesses occur on the scalp skin, and they are of the kinds of knots, which contain the tunics that are to them sacks: as if they themselves were scratched chickens.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And their kinds are many.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	From them are the fat ones: and from them are those that contain moisture similar to clay: and from them are those that contain moisture similar to friable and mushy: and from them are similar ones, and from them are those that are hard like stone.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the incision of all, and their removal is not fearful, as long as it does not make opposition to the artery at their incision.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the operation in their incision is, that it is tried with an instrument, whose form comes after these, which is called Intromissus, until you know what it contains.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if it is that which contains moisture, then dry it by incision according to the length of the surface incision: in this form.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	Begin with a section using a straight line b. to the line g. When the moisture is cleared, then scrape off the dried skin (kistin) that contains that moisture, and do not let anything remain from it completely.
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	For many times it returns if something remains from it.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then soak cotton in Egyptian oil, if it is present: and if not, in water and salt: and fill the wound with it, and let it remain until another day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	For it will corrode what remains from the skin.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then repeat over it with Egyptian oil second and third, and if you need it, until you trust that nothing remains from the skin, then care for the wound with oil until it heals.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	If the abscess contains a thick knot: then dry it according to this form, with a cutting tool having the form of a cross: and insert nails between the grooves of the cut, and scrape it from all parts: and try your strength in extracting the skin that contains it.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	But if the artery opposes you, then do what I will tell you next.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And similarly do in the stone abscess, from the cut and cure, as we said.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And the cut on the stone abscess is easier: because it has little blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes there are some of these abscesses in the head in certain people, with whom there is no moisture at all.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	Which is: because I cut on the abscess in the head of an old woman, and I found the abscess as a solid and hard, rough, white stone, which could not be broken: and if someone hits it with it throwing, it wounds itself.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	In other head abscesses that occur, however, besides these abscesses that happen in the heads of children and around the roots of the ears, a section of all of them should be a superficial cut.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or make an incision in them always from the lower part of them, so that the course of the pus may be relieved towards the lower parts.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then take care of those with what is appropriate for their cure.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	¶ On the section of Strophularia in the neck.
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	These abscesses often occur in the neck, and under the armpits, and in the groins: and sometimes they occur in the rest of the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And over those that occur in the neck, there is one and many: and they are generated from each other: and every Strophularia from them is within its own tunic, as it is in knots and abscesses of the head, as we have narrated.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	And the species of these Strophularia are many.
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	And from them indeed are stony: and from them are those which contain moistures: and from them are evil ones, which do not obey the cure.
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	In that therefore which you see of good disposition from among them, whose manifest is near the color of the skin, and moves to all parts, and is not annexed with the nerves of the neck, nor with the guidegium, nor with the artery, nor is deep: it is necessary that you cut it with a superficial cut from the upper part to the lower part of the body by a line, b. by a line, g., and scrape off the skin from all parts: and extend two lips of the skin with a hook, or with many hooks, if you need it, as we have said in abscesses of the head, and extrahe it gradually.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And it is an additional precaution that the vein or nerve does not get injured.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And it should be a blunt, not sharp, knife: so as not to add your hand with the incision, or disturb the weak, and cut what is not necessary.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	But if you cut a vein, or an artery, and it prevents you from the operation, then place in the wound some powdered zeig, or certain powders that stop bleeding, and bind the wound, and leave it until the sharpness of the abscess subsides, and the wound becomes soft: or it begins to putrefy.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	For the blood is stopped then. So go back to your operation until you complete it.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then examine with your index finger, if there remains anything from the small strophuli: so cut them, and clean them.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	But if there is a large vein in the root of the strophuli: then it is necessary not to cut that strophuli from its root: but it is necessary to tie it with doubled strong thread, and leave it until it falls off without harm.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then fill the wound with old cotton, which you have already immersed in Egyptian oil.
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then take care of it.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	But if the strophuli is cut entirely, then it is necessary to gather the two wound lips: and sew it immediately, after you see that there is no excess remaining.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	But if you see that there is excess remaining due to the size of the strophuli, then it is necessary to extend to cutting its root, and removing it: and apply the suture as we said.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And whatever from the strophuli contains moisture, pierce it with a shallow puncture: so that the place of its maturity appears to you: and place the puncture below the body, as we said.
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	After the perforation, apply liniment with ointment and similar substances to cauterize the remaining part affected by decay until you see that the wound is clean. Then treat it with a generative ointment of flesh until it heals.
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	Concerning the sectioning of the epiglottis from an abscess within the throat due to an accident.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter 43.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	The ancients performed this sectioning of the epiglottis, and I have not seen anyone in our land who has done it; and this is the writing of their words.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	However, in those who have a synanche, the sectioning of the epiglottis should be avoided, since it cannot be done through that, because all veins and lung are weak.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	But in those who have a hot abscess in the mouth, throat, or both jaws, when there is no illness in the channel, one should use sectioning of the epiglottis to avoid the danger that occurs from prefication.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	Therefore, when we want to do this, we should cut the epiglottis under three or four circles of the epiglottis, with a small section through its width, in that which is between two circles by quantity, which is a section in a soft place, not in cartilage: and this place is convenient for the section, because it is free from flesh, and veins are far from it.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	If the physician is timid, then one should stretch the skin of the throat with a needle.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then he should open the skin, until when it reaches the channel: avoid veins, if he sees anything from them.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then he should cut the soft part that we mentioned: and it is indicated over the sectioning of the channel from phlegm that exits from it, because it is broken, and the division of the voice.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And let the open wound heal at some time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	Therefore, when the hour comes when the preformed foreskin is feared to be removed, gather the two lips of the wound and suck only the skin without cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then administer medicines that cause flesh to grow until it is healed.
Inquit Albucasis.	Says Albucasis,
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	The summary of this conversation we have narrated is not an explanation unless when they see that some of these abscesses has already filled the throat of the sick person: and the sick person was lifted up over death, and he wished to be cut off from his breath: they went to cut the epiglottis, so that the sick person could breathe over the wound with some breathing, and be saved from death: and for this reason they ordered the open wound to be left until the malice of the illness is consumed, and its malice lasts for three days, and it is as if it is itself: then they ordered the wound to be sucked and cared for until it is healed.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And that which I saw myself is that one maidservant took a knife, and sent it with her into her throat, and it struck with it the part of the trachea.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	And I was called to heal her, and I found her groaning, as is the groaning of the dead.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	Therefore I exposed the wound, and I found blood that had come out of the wound in small amount.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	Therefore I was confident that she had not cut the vein, nor the artery: and air was going out from the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	Therefore I quickly sucked the wound and cared for it until it was healed: and nothing happened to the maidservant, except a hoarse voice: and she returned after days to a better condition of her limbs.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	I advise therefore that I say: That in the cutting of the Epiglottis there is no fear.
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	¶ On the cutting of the Hernia of the neck.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 44.
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This swelling called Hernia of the neck is a large abscess according to the color of the body: and it is much in women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	And it is according to two modes: for either it is natural: or it is accidental.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	In the natural one certainly there is no skill.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	But in the accidental one indeed it is according to two modes: of which one is similar to the fat knots.
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	And the other mode is similar to the abscess that is made from the knotting of the artery.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And in it there is fear, and it is not necessary to make a presumption against it with iron, unless in that which is small: and you prove it, and investigate it with the intromission.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If therefore you find it similar to the fat knot, and it is not suspended with any vein: then cut it, as the knots are cut: and extract it with that which contains from the chest, if it is in the chest: and if not, then examine all of it.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for the place with that which is necessary from the cure, until it is healed.
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	¶ On the cutting of the species of Knots.
Caput XLV.	Chapter 45.
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many kinds of knots, and I have already said all the kinds of them in the division: and it is necessary that I should tell here the difference between a Knot, and an Extrusion: since it causes doubt.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say therefore, that when an Extrusion is heat, and fever, and very violent pain, until the boiling over of excess is sedated, and completion of putrefaction: then indeed fever and heat are quieted.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	When dealing with a wound that is not inflamed, there is no heat, fever, or pain, and it is contained within its own pus, which is a sac specific to it and corresponds to the color of the body: and its beginning is like chickpeas, and it becomes like lentils, and there are larger and smaller ones.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And they are of two kinds: either fatty: or they contain moisture.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colors of moisture are many, as I said in the division.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	Therefore, when you come to the treatment of a wound, you must try it and examine it first with the instrument called the Intromissus, according to its form as it appears in the chapter that follows.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the method of examining a wound and all wounds is as follows: you take this instrument and insert it into the moistest part that you find in the wound: and you gradually turn your fingers with it until you know that the instrument has penetrated the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then your last hand according to the measure of the size of the wounds.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then remove the Intromissus and examine what has come out at its tip.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If therefore it comes out running moisture, whatever the color is: then dry it with a superficial cut, as I said in the other wounds.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	And if no moisture comes out at the tip of the Intromissus, then you know that it is fatty: so dry it with a cut having the form of a cross, in this form as I taught you: and suspend it with hooks, and scrape off the skin from all parts with facility: and guard the pus if you can above it, so that you can remove it along with the wound.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	But if the pus is broken into pieces during the operation, and it is not possible to remove it whole, often this happens: then remove it piece by piece until there is nothing left of it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if something remains from it, too little or too much, the knot returns according to the most.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	But if it overcomes you and something remains from it, then fill the wound at your completion with certain corrosive powders: sharp, and bind the wound, and place above it what sits the pus hot, and care for it with the remaining cure until it is healed.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	Therefore if the knot is large, then cut its two lips, and care for it with that which fleshens.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	But if to you the opposite vein of the pulsatilla, or not pulsatilla, then hasten, and fill the place with crushed zegi, and leave it bound for two days, or three, until the wound rots, and the boil of blood ceases: then return to cutting that which remains from the knot.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	¶ On the outside instruments for cutting and piercing.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter 46.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	From these are the shapes of introducers, and they are of three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	For indeed it is large, and from them it is medium, and from them it is small.
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	Let them be made of iron awl of the ends of squares properly, so that they quickly enter into the boil.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the shapes of experiencers, and not, that is, piercing: and one of them is named beris, that is, piercing: and they are of three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	For indeed it is large, and medium, and small.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	They are joined, so that they investigate through them boils, and exits, and fistulas, and buboes from what is between them from the bones.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are made round, clean, soft, like the large awl which has seats, from citrine indeed, or from air, or iron, or silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And better than them are those made from citrine.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And they are made from black lead, which come together so that through them they experiment with fistulas, whose concavity is reflections, so that they reflect with their own softness along with those reflections.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	And they are again of three kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	Because from them are long, from them medium, and from them short, according to the quantity of the amplitude of the fistula and its stricture.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The form of Uncinates, and they are of many kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	Because from them are simple, that is, those in which is one curve: and they are of three kinds as you see, Large, Medium, and Small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And from them are Uncinates blind: and they are of three kinds.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And from them are Uncinates having two curves, and they are of three kinds: and from them are Uncinates having three curves, and they are of three kinds: and all of these are necessary in their place.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	And these are the forms of Scalpels, by which they cut and exfoliate Nodos, and abscesses: and they are of three kinds: because from them is large, medium, and small.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their extremities by which the section is made are sharp, other extremities are not sharp: and they are not placed thus, except that with them is made a bandage in the exfoliation of Nodos at the fear of incision of the vein, or nerve: and that the sick may be healed by it, and find some tranquility for a little from the burning which he found at the exfoliation of abscesses.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are Magnifying Glasses, and they are of three kinds.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made from air, and they are like a Ray, with which is made alcohol: and in the broad extremity there is a hidden punctum Spatium: and in it runs to the interior and exterior when you want, as you see.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The form of pus that hides between the fingers, at the location of the boil opening: and the sick do not feel them, and they are of three kinds, large, medium, and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	The forms of the wounds through which blood flow is cut off: and they are of three kinds, large, medium, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	Let them be made of air or yellow, round, slightly long, as you see: and let they be at the delicacy.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And it is necessary that these forms of the wounds be large and small with you: so that you cut off the blood through them with speed in need, and then when there is no medicine present with you.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	But you will not use them in the cutting of blood in every place of the body, and you will not use them except in fleshy places: as the backs of the legs, and the hips, and the backs of the arms, and the breasts, and the belly, and the groin, and similar to these, from fleshy places, moist.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes they are made of them small instruments similar to the husks of beans, according to their form: by which blood is cut off when it flows from the place of phlebotomy, or at the incision of the vein, or artery: and sometimes they are made of them round according to this form.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	¶ Of the care of human breasts which resemble the breasts of women.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter 47.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	Sometimes the breasts of certain men swell at the fullness of sleep (that is, when they begin to become dirty in sleep) until they resemble the breasts of women: and remain pustulous foully.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Whoever dislikes this (practice), it is necessary for them to cover the breasts with a lunar incision, according to this form from line b to line g. Then they should remove the skin entirely, including the fat.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Then they should fill the wound with a flesh-colored medicament.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Afterwards, gather the two edges of the wound with a suture and care for it until it heals.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	If, however, the breast declines towards the lower parts and becomes soft due to its size, as often happens with women: then it is necessary to make two incisions on its upper sides, each of which contains the other at their ends, until one line containing the smaller one is formed, according to this form from line b to line g. Then they should remove the skin that is between the two lips, and take off the fat, and administer what was said about the suture and powders, which is necessary for healing, until it is healed.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	If, however, the incision does not hold together as it should due to the restlessness of the sick person or because of the flow of blood: then it is necessary to fill the wound with a corrosive ointment immersed in cotton, and leave it until it corrodes what remains of the fat.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	Regarding the puncturing of abscesses, which occurs under the breasts.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter 48.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These abscesses that occur under the breasts are of a type of hard strophularia, which contain kistas, and from these are those that contain moistures.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Therefore, those that are from these that contain moistures should be dried with a lunar incision, according to this form from line b to line g, when everything that is in the abscess is drained out of pus, then fill it with old cotton and leave it until another day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then remove the bandage and treat it with an appropriate ointment until it heals.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If the abscess is of the type of Strophularia knots, then cut it above, as we said in the section on Strophularia evenly.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	If the wound extends so that it can emit pus, then apply a cauterizer to it according to what we said in the previous one.
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	On the section of abscesses that occurs due to artery and vein.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter 49.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When the artery is broken and the skin that is above it is consolidated, an abscess often occurs from this: and similarly, an abscess and swelling also occur in veins.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it is known that the abscess and swelling are due to the artery and vein, are: because when the abscess is due to the artery, it is long, collected in the deep part of the body: and when you press the abscess with your fingers, you feel as if there is a noise to it.
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is due to vein, is round in an obvious part of the body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And the section on this abscess is an error, and especially that which is under the armpits, and in the groins, and on the neck, and in many parts of the body: and it is great and very large.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	Therefore it must be avoided with iron in its care, and that which is from them also is at the extremities, or on the head, must be avoided.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	Therefore on that which is from them due to inflation of the artery opening, find in the skin section in length.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the section with hooks, then the artery: and free it from the tunics, until it is uncovered.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then insert the needle under it and make it penetrate to the other side, and tie the artery with a double thread in two places, as I taught you in the extraction of the two arteries that are in the temples.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then prick the place that is between the two ligaments with a lancet, until all the blood that is in it comes out and the abscess is dissolved.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then apply the treatment that generates pus until the ligaments fall off: then care for it with suitable ointments until it heals.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	If it is an abscess due to the cutting of the vein, then you must hold what is possible for you to remove from the abscess with the skin.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then insert the needle under the place that you held with your hand, and make it penetrate: and let there be a double thread on it, until you remove it from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then tie it with the abscess with a good ligature: according to what I told you in the ligature of the vein, from two parts with two ends of the thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	But if you fear that the thread will be removed, then insert another needle with another thread under the abscess entirely at the incision of the needle: press and tie your thread in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then cut the abscess in the middle of itself, until when it comes out what is in it: then cut off the excess skin, and let go what is tied from it.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then place on it a compress that you dipped in wine and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then apply the treatment that is made with lint and ointment until it heals.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	On the abscess that happens from the twisting of nerves.
Caput L.	Chapter L.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	Just as it happens that an abscess occurs in an artery and vein, similarly, an abscess can occur in nerves: this happens to them from a blow or from excessive labor, and the like. It is most common in the places of helpers, or calcanei, and in every place where the movements of the joints occur: and it is a heavy abscess.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	Its color is similar to that of the rest of the body, and it occurs in many positions without pain: and when it is compressed with great force, the sick person feels in it a sensation similar to paralysis.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	And it is not an abscess that is aggregated in the depth of the body, but rather it is under the skin, and it moves to every part, and does not go to the front, nor before, nor back to the rear parts.
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	Therefore, what is from them in the joints, it is not necessary that it be approached with iron.
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Perhaps contraction will occur.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	But in that which is from them in the head, or in the forehead, pierce the skin with a lancet.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If therefore it is a small abscess, then hold it with forceps, and cut it off from the root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if it is large, then suspend it with a hook, and excise it: then remove it, and gather the wound with a stitch: and care for it until it is healed.
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	About cutting abscesses that occur in the belly.
Caput LI.	Chapter LI.
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	It often happens to some men in their bellies, and in the rest of their bodies, that they have warts, which are called fungous growths, by similarity with mushrooms.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	Whose root is thin, and their head is thick, and their lips are turned over.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And among them is little: and among them is that which is highly valued greatly.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	Indeed, I have seen a man, and in his belly were two testicles, which were more like other things than anything else: there was no difference between them, they were white, small roots, and they faced each other, and they were found, and moisture always ran from them.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	I therefore cut them, and I found in the weight of one as if X and 8 ounces and in the other as if 6 ounces. And the operation in their cutting is that you consider then, if the sick person is wet, and the color of the testicles is white, moist, delicate roots: then cut him with a broad spatula, and there be cauterization in your presence in fire.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	For often blood is driven out of its cutting: therefore hurry if the blood overcomes you, then cauterize it.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	If you see the sick person afraid and timid from the cutting with iron, then take a thread made of lead properly, and tie with it a cloth: whose method we have said, and leave it for two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add to the stricture of lead.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	Therefore do not cease to tie lead, whenever it is pressed on the testicles, until it is cut off, and falls by itself without labor.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	But if the testicles are coarse of roots, then in their cutting there is something fearful and timid: especially what is in the belly.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	However it is possible to cut its middle.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it, so that it does not return.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for it, until the wound is healed.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And beware that you do not presume to cut testicles which are of brown color, few senses, foul appearance: for indeed it is a cancerous abscess: and I will come with the remembrance of Cancer after this.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	Translation: On the Treatment of Umbilical Hernias.
Caput LII.	Chapter 52.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	Umbilical hernias occur for many reasons.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Or from a tear in the abdomen, which is above the belly, and protrudes through it, or an intestine, according to what happens in other ruptures.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or from blood that flows from the vein, or from the artery, as was previously mentioned.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or from the abdominal wall being too loose in that area.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	If it is due to a tear in the abdomen and the protrusion is through the thigh, then it has a similar color to a pustule: and it is painless, without pain: and it appears to be in different positions.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is due to the protrusion of an intestine, then its position is with that which we have mentioned, of greater diversity.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	Therefore, when you press it with your fingers, it disappears: then it returns, and perhaps it is with that sound: and it is greatly enlarged at the entrance of the bath, and the effort is violent.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	But if it is due to moisture, it is painless, then it does not disappear when you press it with your hand, nor is it compressed, nor does anything else happen.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	If it is due to blood, then with these signs it appears to be a pustule turning black from the slope.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	But if it is due to flesh born, then it is a heavy, thick, hard pustule, and it is shaped according to one quantity.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	But if it is due to looseness, then the touch of it is gentle.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the operation in it is, so that you consider at that time, if the umbilical hernia is due to blood from the artery, or the vein, or looseness: then it is necessary to be prevented from its treatment.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For in that case there is fear and trembling, as I taught you in the chapter where I said about abscesses due to the artery and vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	But if the prominence of the navel is due to the intestine or a fistula: then you must order the sick person, as much as possible, to hold their breath and stand upright.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then signs with the cautery around the navel of the whole body.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Then order him to lie down on his back between your hands on his back.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then circle with a broad-bladed knife around the navel on the spot that you indicated with the cautery.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Then extend the middle of the abscess towards the upper parts, with a large needle.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then tie him around the navel strongly with a strong thread, or with a silk cord from a strong silk ligature: and let there be a knot in the ligature.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the middle of the abscess extended above the ligature.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If therefore you find that it is already captured by the ligature: then remove the ligature, and insert your index finger into it, and push the intestine towards the interior of the abdomen: and if you find a fistula, then take it with the needle, and cut off its excess.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	But if the opposite is against you, the artery or vein: then circle it much.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your operation.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And take two needles, and insert into them two strong threads: and insert two needles into the circumference that you made around the abscess in the form of a cross, which you make to pierce.
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then tie the abscess in four places on the needle: and if you wish, remove the needle, and let go of the place, until the extended flesh rots: and falls off by itself: or cut it when it becomes thin and rotten.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then take care of that (wound) with the appropriate medicine until it heals.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	But if the prominence of the umbilicus is from the flesh or moisture, then you should drain the abscess as we mentioned earlier.
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And remove the blood or moisture that you find in it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then take care of that (wound) with the appropriate medicine that hardens the area.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	¶ On the treatment of Cancer.
Caput LIII.	Chapter 53.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	We have already mentioned the division of cancer species and how to treat it with medicines, and we must be careful with its treatment with iron, so that it does not ulcerate: and we said that cancer generated in the womb, and precautions for its treatment.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients said that when cancer is in a place where it can be eradicated, such as cancer in the breasts or thighs, and similar places located in the limbs to remove the whole of it, especially when it is small and beginning.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	But when it is old and large, one should not approach it.
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	For I could not heal anyone from that: nor did I see anyone before me who reached that.
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the operation on it, when it is located as we mentioned, is to go ahead and dissolve the weak part from black bile several times.
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then if you find blood flow with obvious fullness.
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the weak part with preparation, where it will be located with the operation.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then insert hooks that suit it into the cancer.
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Then drain it from all parts with the skin, according to examination, until nothing remains of its roots: and let the blood flow, and do not cut it quickly, but express the places and wipe off the thick blood entirely by your hand, or with whatever is possible there from instruments.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If the unevenness of the blood flow due to an incision in the artery or vein bothers you, then cauterize the vein until the blood stops flowing.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the wound itself along with the other treatment until it heals.
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	On the Care of Hydrops.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter 45.
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	Now we have already discussed the division of hydrops species, how water accumulates, and all its symptoms, as well as its treatment with remedies.
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	And the one that is cured with iron is only the species of ascites alone, and it does not approach with iron the species of tympanitis: nor does the species of hydrops entirely: for that is fatal.
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	When you have already been cured of this species of hydrops tympanitis with remedies, and your treatment did not include: then consider.
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.	For if the patient has already become weak, or there is weakness with him other than hydrops: such as if it is with him cough, or diarrhea, and similar things: then beware that you do not treat him with iron: for that is fear.
Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.	But if you see the patient overflowing with strength, and there is no other illness with him except hydrops alone: and he is not a child, nor an old person: then the method of operation in him is, that you lift up the patient standing between your hands, and the assistant after him will press his belly with his hand pushing the water towards the lower part of the ribs.
Deinde accipe spatumile spinosum, secundum hanc formam.	Then take a sponge of thistle in this form.
Sit duarum partium acutarum, longum, acutae extremitatis sicut Spatumile.	It should be two parts sharp, long, and sharp at the ends like a sponge.
Verumtamen in eo sit quiddam breuitatis paulatim, ut non pertranseas cum eo apud operationem usque ad intestinum, et laedas ipsum.	However, there should be something of brevity gradually in it, so that you do not pass with him to the operation up to the intestine, and you do not hurt it.
Deinde considera.	Then consider.
Nam si est generatio Hydropisis ex parte intestinorum, tunc oportet ut elongeris cum sectione ab umbilico quantitate trium digitorum, ad inferiora in directo eius supra pectinem.	For if the generation of Hydropisis is from the part of the intestines, then it is necessary to extend with a cut from the navel by the quantity of three fingers, to the lower parts in a straight line above the pecten.
Si uero generatio Hydropisis est propter aegritudinem epatis: tunc sit sectio tua sinistra ab umbilico tribus digitis.	But if the generation of Hydropisis is due to pain in the liver, then your cut should be on the left side from the navel by the quantity of three fingers.
Et si generatio eius est propter splenem, tunc sit sectio in latere dextro: et non oportet etiam ut sit sectio in latere super quod uult iacere infirmus, ut non currant superfluitates ad illum locum debilem.
