Deinde ponatur super membrum: et digitus sit super foramen quod dixi, donec quando tenemus uentosam: dum indigemus, auferamus digitum, et egredietur uapor super illud foramen, et soluetur uentosa statim.	Then place it on the member: and the finger should be on the hole that I said, until we hold the sponge: while we need it, we remove the finger, and steam comes out of that hole, and the sponge dissolves immediately.
Deinde igni licinium secundum modum suum, et itera eam, si indiges illa.	Then light the linen cloth according to its usual manner, and repeat it if you need it.
In Ventosa autem quae administratur in aegritudine pleuresis cum aqua, non est uirga transuersa, neque foramen: et non administratur, nisi quia impletur aqua, et ponitur super membrum tantum.	In the sponge that is administered in the illness of pleurisy with water, there is no twisted rope, nor hole: and it is not administered unless because the water is full, and it is placed on the member only.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Et haec Ventosa quanto plus est magna, ut capiat aquam multam, est melior.	And this sponge, the larger it is, the better it is to hold much water.
¶ De suspensione Sanguisugarum.	¶ On the suspension of Bloodletting Cups.
Caput XCIX.	Chapter 99.
Sanguisugae non administrantur in pluribus, nisi in quibus membris non est possibilis positio uentosarum, propter paruitatem eorum, sicut labium, et gingiua, et eis similia.	Bloodletting cups are not administered in many places, unless in those where it is impossible to place the sponges, due to their size, such as the lip, and the jaw, and similar things.
Aut in membro denudato a carne, sicut digitus, et nasus, et eis similia.	Or in the member bare of flesh, such as the finger, and the nose, and similar things.
Et qualitas utendi eis est: ut ueneris ex Sanguisugis quae sunt in aquis dulcibus, mundis a putredinibus.	And the quality of using them is: that you go from bloodsuckers which are in sweet waters, clean from corruption.
Deinde dimittantur die et nocte in aqua dulci, donec famelicae sint, et non remaneat in uentre earum aliquid.	Then they should be released day and night into sweet water, until the bloodsuckers are hungry, and nothing remains in their belly.
Deinde euacuetur corpus in primis cum phlebotomia, et cum uentosis.	Then the body will be purified first with bloodletting, and with vomiting.
Deinde absterge membrum infirmi, donec rubeat.	Then wipe the weak member until it reddens.
Postea ponantur super ipsum.	Afterwards they will be placed on top of it.
Cum ergo implentur, et cadunt, et est possibilis suctio loci cum uentosa, tunc est magis ultimum in iuuamento: et si non, tunc ablue locum cum aceto.	When they are full and fall, and it is possible to suck the location with vomiting, then it is more final in the cure: and if not, then wash the place with vinegar.
Deinde cum aqua multa, et fricetur, et exprimatur.	Then with much water, and rub, and express.
Quod si prolongatur cursus sanguinis post casum Sanguisugarum, et est illud resudando: tunc infunde pannum lini in aqua frigida, et pone ipsum desuper, donec abscindatur resudatio.	If the course of blood extends after the death of bloodsuckers, and it is that dripping: then pour linen cloth into cold water, and place it on top, until the dripping is cut off.
Quod si multiplicatur sanguis, tunc pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, aut gallas, et similia eis ex stipticis: donec abscindatur sanguis.	If the blood increases, then powder on top of it sage leaves crushed, or galbanum, and similar things from stoptics: until the blood is cut off.
Aut ponantur super locum medietates fabarum excorticatarum: et dimittantur, donec adhaereant fabae in loco, nam sanguis abscinditur.	Or they will be placed on top of the location of half-peeled beans: and they will be released, until the beans stick in the place, because the blood is cut off.
Et oportet si necessaria est iteratio Sanguisugarum, quando est possibile, mutare eas.	And it is necessary if it is necessary to repeat the bloodsuckers, when it is possible, to change them.
Si autem prohibentur Sanguisugae a suspensione, tunc abstergatur locus cum sanguine recenti.	But if bloodsuckers are prevented from hanging, then wash the place with fresh blood.
Aut fige acum in locis, donec egrediatur aliquid ex sanguine.	Or fix a needle in the places, until something comes out of the blood.
Deinde ponantur, nam ipsae quando sentiunt aliquid ex sanguine, adhaerent statim.	Then they will be placed, because when they feel something from the blood, they stick immediately.
Quando ergo uis ut cadant, pulueriza super eas aliquid ex aloe trito, aut salem, aut cinerem: et cadent statim.	When you wish for them to fall out, sprinkle powder on them from a crushed aloe, or salt, or ash: and they will fall out immediately.
¶ Partis Secundae Finis.	¶ Second Part Conclusion.
¶ Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars III.	¶ Book of Surgery by Albucasis Part III.
¶ Sermo uniuersalis de restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus.	¶ Universal Speech on the Restoration, Dislocation, and Cure of Sprains, and Similar Matters.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Hoc Capitulum etiam multotiens est necessarium in arte Medicinae, et est restauratio fracturae, et dislocationis accidentium in ossibus.	This chapter is also often necessary in the art of medicine, and it is the restoration of fractures and dislocations that occur in bones.
Scitote o Filii, quia iactant se de hoc Capitulo stolidi medicorum et uulgi, et qui non inspexerunt unquam antiquorum librum, neque legerunt ex eo literam.	Know, O children, that foolish physicians and the common people, and those who have never examined the ancient book nor read a letter from it, boast about this chapter.
Et propter hanc caussam fit, quod iste modus ex scientiis in terra nostra est priuatus.	And for this reason, this method is deprived of our knowledge on earth.
Et ego non obuiaui in eo unquam bono omnino, et non adeptus sum ex eo illud, quod sum adeptus nisi propter longitudinem lectionis librorum antiquorum, et studium super intellectum eorum, donec extraxi scientiam illius ex eis.	And I have never boasted in it at all, and I have not obtained from it that which I have obtained unless for the length of reading ancient books and the study beyond understanding them until I extracted the knowledge of it from them.
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	Then I adhered to it by experience and study throughout the length of my life.
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.	And now I have described to you in this chapter all that it contains of my knowledge: and after my experience passed over it, after I abbreviated it for you, and freed it from the burden of length, and abbreviated it at the end of abbreviation, and showed it at the end of declination: and I formed many forms in it from the forms of instruments that are administered in it, since it is from the addition of declination, just as I did in two preceding chapters.
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	¶ Summary and collections from the existence of bone fractures, from those that their preliminary mention is necessary before we begin the remembrance of the limbs of the broken and various, if each one.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	In the prologue of this chapter, we must say some basic words and headings that require understanding in order to reach the truth of these matters: namely, so that you and those who are ready know, or learn, this noble art, and others from us.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	I say therefore that when a fracture, or dislocation, or twist, or accident happens to someone: then it is necessary to proceed first to bleeding him, and to dissolving him, or both at once: if nothing prevents, such as weakness of strength: or he is one of those who are very old, or decrepit: or it is a time of very intense heat, or very intense cold.
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	Then he should be content with his food, with cool spices, and meat of birds, and of sheep: and prohibit wine, and coarse meat, and to be filled with food and all food that fills the veins with blood.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	Until when he is secure from the hot abscess, and does not fear the flow of matter to the member: then the sick person should return to his first diet with which he was used to custom.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	When therefore the broken jaw begins to be restored, then it is necessary for the sick person to be fed with nutritious food in great abundance, coarse, heavy, in which there is viscosity: such as food made from cooked wheat with water, and rice, and meat, and feet, and bellies of cattle, and eggs, and fresh fish: and thick wine, and similar to those.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	For this diet makes the healing of the fracture faster, and better.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	And know that when bones are fractured in men who are in their first old age, and the decrepit, it is not possible for them to be continuously and consolidated according to their natural nature always, because of the dryness of their members: and they are consolidated and continued what is from them at the end of lenity, as bones of small children.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	However, nature attaches something similar to glue to the fractured bone from all parts, which contains a certain thickness that adheres and binds it together, until they are gradually united and bound together again, until it comes to the end of its strength and firmness, just as it was in the beginning, until something does not prevent it from performing its functions: for this reason, it is necessary to place nourishment for the weak foods, in which there is heaviness, viscosity, and thickness, as we have said.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	And you should know that the appearance of fractures is different according to the diversity of the members: for a fracture of the leg is different from a fracture of the skull, and a fracture of the ribs is different from a fracture of the backbone: and similarly, all other members are different from one another: and I come with the remembrance of all the species of fractures explained in their respective chapters distinct from one another.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	The species of bone fracture also vary within themselves.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	Since it can be broken into a curved shape, apart from what happens to it in the form of stars.
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	And sometimes the fracture of it is according to the length of the bone: and its splinters, that is, stars, and additions proceeding, as are in a reed when it is fitted with a knife for writing.
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	And not proceeding: and there is a fracture with a wound and disruption in the head: and it is a small crack.
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	And there is a proper skill or tool for the restoration of each species, according to which the remembrance of it will come, distinct in its own places.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	And from the fact that the fracture of the bone is known, there is its crookedness and its prominence: and its appearance to the senses, and its sound when you grasp it with your hand.
Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	When there is no apparent twisting in the location, nor does a noise occur when you touch the bone with agitation, and no significant pain is found in the weak person: then there is no fracture there, but it is possible that there may be a slight crack or twist. Therefore, it is not necessary to move it with your hand and compress it entirely, but rather place something soft on it from the medicines, of which mention is made, that fits the location: then it should be bound tightly with a thin bandage.
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And know that when the location is bent and torn into two, apart from what happens to it, nevertheless all part of its own is removed: then it is necessary for you to begin from your hour to rectify it, equaling it before it occurs to it a hot abscess.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	But if a hot abscess occurs to it, then let it go for several days, until the abscess is quiet.
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	Then equal it according to whatever way can be done from the alleviation and skill.
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	And know that the restoration of it, and its equaling, is easier than bone, in which happenings occur to it.
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	Then bind it, according to what comes to your memory of it.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	But if the happenings are in the bone, then it is necessary to extend this member of the broken one from two parts, if the hand is, or the foot: or with your hand, if the member is small: or with two ropes, or with a rope and a hand.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	And your position should be where you place the member on the equal location, according to its natural shape, until when the parts of the broken member are extended: then try to make those additions all with skill, and according to whatever way you can in their places: and beware according to your strength, so that pain does not occur to the weak person through your operation, nor injury: and try according to your strength, to apply one of two bones with its joint, according to better forms.
Et oportet in illa hora, ut tentes et tangas ipsum manu tua.	In that hour, you must attempt and touch it with your own hand.
Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	If therefore you see something different there, correct it, and make it even by the amount of your virtue.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	And beware of strong extension and strong compression, as many fools do.
Multotiens enim faciunt accidere per operationem illam suam apostema calidum, aut contractionem in membro: sicut iam uidimus illud ex operationibus eorum multotiens.	For they often cause harm by their operation, a hot abscess or contraction in the limb: as we have already seen from their operations many times.
Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	Then connect after the equalization and proper operation, the tightness of that limb, and its quiet and tranquility: and warn the weak one on it.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua.	And make him be careful, not to move it in his own hours of vigilance, and his sleep, its rotation, its agitation, and its emission, and all its movements by his last virtue.
Et ut caueat, ne sit positio membri positio cum qua sequatur dolor.	And let him be careful, that the position of the limb is not a position from which pain will follow.
Quod est, quia quando sentit in dispositione positionis membri dolorem, aut laesionem: tunc oportet, ut permutes ipsum ad dispositionem aliam ab illa cum qua non sentiat dolorem.	That is, because when he feels pain in the position of the limb, or injury: then it is necessary to change it to a different position from which he does not feel pain.
Et caue cum illo, ut sit positio eius illa aequalis, recta: ut non accidat in membro tortuositas, quando restauratur.	And let him be careful with it, that that position is equal, straight: so that when the limb is restored, twisting will not occur in it.
Et qualitas stricturae membri fracti est, secundum quod narro.	And the quality of the tightness of the broken limb is as I say.
Scias, quod membra fracta diuersificantur in paruitate sua, et eorum magnitudine, et ipsorum forma.	You know that broken limbs differ in their size, and their magnitude, and their form.
Quae ergo ex eis sunt parua, sicut brachium, et digitus, et focile, et similia eis, tunc oportet, ut sit inuolutio panni mollis, subtilis.	Which therefore from them are small, such as the arm, and finger, and foot, and similar to them, then it is necessary to be a wrapping of soft cloth, thin.
Quae autem ex eis sunt grossa, sicut coxa, et crus, oportet ut sit in eis inuolutio lata, dura.	But which from them are large, such as the thigh, and leg, then it is necessary to be a wrapping of wide, hard cloth.
Quoniam ligamentum latum, connectit membrum magnum, et stringit ipsum ab omni parte strictura aequali, ita quod non ingreditur ipsum macula.	Because the broad ligament connects the large member and binds it from every part with equal tension, so that it does not enter it with a stain.
Deinde incipe post euacuationem tuam ab aequatione ponere linimentum conueniens ad illud, in stuppa leni super locum fracturae ipsius.	Then after your evacuation, place a suitable liniment on the equation after it, on the soft towel over the place of the fracture itself.
Deinde incipe inuoluere ligamentum super locum fracturae ipsius tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod meretur membrum: et stringe manum tuam parumper cum ligamento.	Then begin to roll the ligament over the place of the fracture itself with three or four rolls, according to what the member deserves: and bind your hand a little with the ligament.
Deinde uade cum eo ad partem superiorem a loco fracturae, et stringe minus quam fuit strictura tua, qua strinxisti locum fractum.	Then go with it to the upper part from the place of the fracture, and bind less than your previous binding, by which you bound the place of the fracture.
Deinde elonga te cum inuolutione a loco fracturae parumper, et mollifica stricturam paulatim, donec capias ex loco sano rem magnam.	Then lengthen yourself with the roll from the place of the fracture for a little, and soften the binding gradually, until you take out a great thing from the healthy place.
Deinde accipe uittam aliam, et inuolue eam iterum super locum fractum inuolutionibus.	Then take another clean one, and roll it again over the place of the fracture with rolls.
Postea uade cum inuolutione ad partem inferiorem a fractura.	Then go with the roll to the lower part from the fracture.
Et sit operatio tua in strictura inuolutionis, et mollificatione eius, secundum quod diximus in inuolutione prima superiore.	And your operation should be in the binding of the roll and its softening, according to what we said in the first roll above.
Deinde pone inter inuolutiones ex stuppa leni, aut panno, cum quo aequetur tortuositas fracturae, si est in ea tortuositas: et si non, non ponas in ea aliquid.	Then place between the rolls a soft towel or cloth with which the twisting of the fracture is equal, if there is twisting in it: and if not, you will not place anything on it.
Deinde inuolue super ipsam uittam aliam.	Then roll over that other clean one.
Postea aequa super has inuolutiones astellas decenter factas statim, si non est in loco inflatio, neque apostema calidum.	Then immediately after these well-made stars, if there is no inflation or hot abscess in the place.
Si autem in ea est inflatio, aut apostema: tunc pone super eam quod sedet illud apostema, et auferat inflationem: et dimitte eam aliquot diebus.	But if there is inflation or abscess in it, then place on it what sits that abscess and removes the inflation: and leave it for several days.
Deinde stringe super ipsam tunc astellas.	Then tie around that one star.
Et sint Astellae ex medietatibus cannae latae, rasae, formatae sapienter: aut sint ex ligno unde fiunt cribra, quae fiunt ex pino, aut geraid, id est, ramis palmae, aut calingi: et sit amplitudo omnis Astellae, secundum hanc formam, et hanc eandem figuram.	And the stars should be made from the flat, smooth pieces of bamboo, or from the cribbas made from pine or palm branches, or calingi: and the size of all the stars should be according to this form, and in this same shape.
Verumtamen oportet, ut Astella quae ponitur super ipsam tracturam, sit grossior et latior parumper, quam reliquae Astellae: et longitudo Astellae sit secundum quod licet membro ex magnitudine et paruitate.	However, it is necessary that the star placed on the tractus should be slightly thicker and wider than the other stars, and the length of the star should be according to what fits the member in terms of size and shape.
Deinde stringe super Astellas cum uitta alia, secundum stricturam primam eandem.	Then tie around the stars with another thread, according to the first tightness.
Deinde liga desuper cum filis decenter, secundum quod diximus de strictura: et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae plus: et quanto plus elongatur a fractura sit, strictura minor.	Then tie over it with threads in a proper manner, as we said about the tightness: and it is that your tightness should be more above the place of the fracture: and the further it is from the fracture, the less the tightness.
Et oportet, ut sint fila media in grossitudine et subtilitate, et sint ex lino molli.	And it is necessary that the threads should be of medium thickness and thinness, and they should be made of soft linen.
Quoniam si fila sunt grossa, sicut uidi ex operatione stolidorum ponentium fila sua ex chordis lini tortis, est error magnus: quoniam cadit strictura cum eis extra qualitatem.	For if the threads are thick, as I saw from the operation of stupid people who use their own threads made from twisted linen, it is a great mistake: for the tightness falls outside of its quality with them.
Et fila subtilia iterum non conueniunt: quoniam tu non consequeris per stricturam cum eis illud quod uis.	And thin threads do not come together again: for you will not gather through the tightness with them what you want.
Et non oportet, ut sit inter astellam et astellam minus quam digitus.	And it is not necessary that there should be less than a finger between the stars and the stars.
Quod si laeditur infirmus per extremitates astellarum post stricturam in locis sanis: tunc pone sub eis ex stuppa leni, aut lana carminata, donec nihil laedatur ex illo.	If the weak one is injured by the ends of the stars after the tightness in healthy places, then put under them soft wool or dyed wool until nothing is injured from it.
Quando autem est fractura cum uulnere, et accidit disruptio in cute, ego ueniam cum rememoratione eius in capitulo secundum singularitatem.	But when there is a fracture with a wound, and disruption in the skin occurs, I will come back to it with a remembrance of it in the chapter according to its singularity.
Et scias, quod non omne membrum fractum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis a primo die.	And know that not every broken limb should be bound with stitches from the first day.
Quod est, quia membrum quando est magnum, non oportet ut ponas superipsum astellas, nisi post quinque dies, aut septem, aut plus, secundum securitatem tuam ab euentu apostematis calidi.	Because when a limb is large, it is not necessary to place stitches on it, unless after five days, or seven, or more, according to your caution from the occurrence of hot abscesses.
Et iste est modus emplastrorum, quibus restaurabant antiqui, quae ponuntur super fracturam et dislocationem.	And this is the method of plasters used by ancients, which are placed on a fracture and dislocation.
¶ Modus Emplastri communis abbreuiati, restaurans fracturam, conueniens pluribus complexionibus, praecipue mulieribus, et pueris: quoniam est ex eo super quod non uincit calor, neque frigus.	¶ The common method of the plaster, restoring a fracture, suitable for many constitutions, especially women and children, because it is made of that which does not bind with heat, nor cold.
Et est, ut accipias ex puluere molendini, et est medulla farinae quae pendet in parietibus molendini apud motum molae: et conficias ipsum sicut est, praeter quod cribelles ipsum cum albugine oui: et pone confectionem eius non spissam, neque subtilem.	And it is that you take from the dust of the millstone, and it is the marrow of the flour which hangs in the walls of the mill by the movement of the millstone: and make it thus, except that you grind it with the husk: and place the confection of it not thick, nor thin.
Deinde utere eo.	Then use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, restaurantis fracturam, et dislocationem, et torsionem.	¶ Another method of the plaster, restoring a fracture, and dislocation, and twisting.
Recipe almess, et laudani, et acaciae, et enulae, et mugath: et suc, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V et alethil ʒ XX terantur omnia, et cribellentur, et misceantur cum aqua alethil: aut cum albugine oui, si complexio infirmi est calefacta.	Take of almess, and laudanum, and acacia, and enulae, and mugath: and suc, each ʒ X myrrhae, and both aloes ana ʒ V and alethil ʒ XX they are all ground, and sifted, and mixed with water alethil: or with the husk if the constitution of the patient is heated.
Deinde utere hoc emplastro.	Then use this plaster.
Nam ipsum est bonae compositionis, restaurat ossa fracta uelociter, et confert pluribus hominibus.	For indeed it is of good composition, it restores broken bones quickly, and it binds to many people.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, quod etiam confert fracturae et torsioni.	¶ Another method of the plaster, which also binds a fracture and twisting.
Recipe mugath, et mess, et alteae albae, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX terantur omnia contritione multa, et cribellentur, et conficiantur cum aqua, aut albugine oui: et administrentur.	Recipe for mugwort, and mess (a type of herb), and white alum, of all equal parts 10 grains of myrrh, and of both kinds of aloes 5 grains, of acacia 6 grains, of Armenian bole 20 grains. They should all be well ground together, sifted, and made into a powder with water, or with egg white: and they should be administered.
¶ Modus Emplastri ad iuncturas, et ossa separata ex locis suis: et sedat dolorem accidentem eis, et scissuram ossis, et fracturam.	Method of applying a plaster to joinings, and separated bones from their places: and it soothes the pain caused by them, and the wound of the bone, and the fracture.
Sumatur lana succida, et submergatur in aceto, et oleo decocto: et ponatur super locum.	Take cut wool, and immerse it in vinegar, and boiled oil: and place it on the spot.
Et in hoc quidem Emplastro non est uirtus restaurationis, sed est bonum in sedatione apostematis calidi: et expellit dolores proprie.	And in this plaster there is no power of healing, but it is good for the sedation of hot abscesses: and it expels pain properly.
¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	Method of applying a plaster to heal a broken bone.
Sume folia fici surdi, et folia papaueris syluestris: et tere omnia, et fac emplastrum ex utrisque.	Take the leaves of a wild fig, and the leaves of a wild papyrus: and grind all of them, and make a plaster from both.
¶ Modus Emplastri abbreuiati, administrati apud restaurationem fracturae ossis: et quando tu uis resolutionem residui apostematis.	Method of applying a shortened plaster to heal a broken bone: and when you want the resolution of the remaining abscess.
Recipe radicis alteae, et camomillae, et florum uiolarum, et farinae herbi, omnium ana partem unam: terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum uino, si non est membrum calefactum.	Recipe for the root of white alum, and chamomile, and flowers of violets, and flour of herbs, of all equal parts 1: they should all be ground together, and made into a powder with wine, if it is not a heated member.
Si uero est calefactum, tunc confice illud cum aqua coriandri humidi, aut cum aqua, et utere eo.	But if indeed it is heated, then make it into a powder with water of coriander, or with water, and use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius fortioris in resolutione, quam istud primum, quando accidit apostema durum apud restaurationem membri.	Another method of applying a stronger plaster for the resolution, than this first one, when an hard abscess occurs at the healing of a member.
Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris uiolarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.	Recipe for the roots of althaea, and the seeds of linseed, and balm, and melilot, and safflower, and violets, and chamomile, of each one ounce, they should all be pounded, and then mixed with either willow water, or sweet water, or wine.
Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	All of that according to the warmth of the member, and the peacefulness of its heat.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	Hippocrates indeed did not say in his book that a plaster should be placed on the broken member during its restoration, unless it is made from pitch and oil: nothing else; and he narrated that it should be between the thickness and subtlety.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	Galen indeed saw that things should be placed on the broken member during its restoration, in which there is the drying of heat, such as myrrh, and aloe, and frankincense, and similar to those which we have mentioned.
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	The method of the plaster that brings healing and pain relief.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	Recipe mugwort, and chickpeas, and the hairs of a man's teeth, or the feathers of a bird, and althaea, and equal parts of salt: they should be pounded, and sieved, and made into a plaster.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	However, the quantity that should be made so that it remains a bandage, then dissolved, is such that you consider at that time, if no pain does not occur to the sick person, nor itching, nor move the broken member from its place: then do not dissolve it for many days.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	However, if it happens to him in the place of strong itching, or painful disturbance, or inflation: then hurry, and dissolve it in the hour itself, and remove the plaster from him: and take a soft cloth, or a sea sponge, soft: and immerse it in warm water, and wash with it the place, until the itching is quieted, and the pain sits.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	Then let the limb rest for one hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	Then place on it a piece of clean linen soaked in vinegar and oil, or rose oil: and bind it overnight, until you are sure that the hot abscess has been drained, and the inflation of the member has subsided, and the pain has been removed.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	Then repeat this process gently and apply a small plaster: and do not bind it tightly with your first bandage, and the thin ones with it, until it is healed.
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	If you see that the abscess, and redness, and pain, and inflation, and all the other symptoms have been completely removed, and you need a plaster and bandage, then repeat this as you did in the first place, equally.
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	If none of these things happen to the member, then do not unbind it, unless after three days, or four, or five, or seven.
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	And when you unbind it after twenty days, all of that, according to what appears to you from the solution of the member, as we said, until whenever the fracture sticks and the coagulation of the flesh on it: then also add in the bandage more than your first bandage entirely: and also add in the feeding of the sick person, according to what preceded the memory of it.
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	But if you see that the place of the fracture is already dry and thinned out more than necessary: then know that food is forbidden to reach it.
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	Therefore foment it with warm water at every place where you bind it, and let it be in all three days, and relieve the bandage a little.
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	Through this operation, food reaches the member, and it is healed quickly.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	But that which the ignorant restorers do from the fracture of the member, when it is not restored in the first place, according to what is necessary, and is restored according to its twist, is an error from their operation, and great fear: and if it were right, they would have said this in their books, and operated with it.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	I have not seen any trace of that among them at all, and it is indeed better that it not be done.
¶ De factura accidente in capite.	On the formation of an accidental deformity on the head.
Caput III.	Chapter 3.
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	The species of fractures are diverse, and their shapes are many, and their causes are distinct.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	For a fracture is that which is caused by impact with an axe: and the impact removes the entire bone until it reaches the periosteum, which is beneath the bone, just as it does in wood: and because of this, this species of fracture is called Axial.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	Or the sword cuts something of the bone, and it cuts its face, and the cut does not penetrate to the end of it: and this species of fracture is called Kalán, that is, Luxation absolutely.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	And there is a wound of two fractures, either large or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	And there is a fracture that is crushing or grinding: and its cause is impact with a stone, or a fall on a stone, or similar things.
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	And this fracture is also penetrating, which approaches the periosteum, which is beneath the bone: or it is on the face of the bone: and this wound is of two fractures, either large or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	And there is a fracture that is hidden in the bone in its thinness of hair: and it is a small crack, and because of this, this species of fracture is called Capillary.
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	And there is a fracture that is caused by an accident, or by impact with a stone, and similar things, which cause the lamina of the bone to enter its interior, and it forms a concavity in the place: just as happens to copper pots when they are hit, and part of them enters their interior.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	This happens most frequently in the heads of wet bones, such as the heads of children's bones.
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	All these species of fractures are separate, and I will come back to the memory of all that in its place.
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	We know all these types of fractures by examining them, and inquiring about them with probes, and removing the rotten flesh that is on them.
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	The species of the capillary is known by this, that it is scraped over the bone, and cleaned, and smeared on top with cauterizer, for the fracture appears black.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	In the treatment of fractures, first consider the symptoms of the infirm: then if you see from the symptoms that it clearly indicates fear, such as vomiting cholera, and extension, and loss of understanding, and loss of voice, and syncopis, and acute fever, and outflow of the eyes, and redness of them, and similar to these in many positions, certainly not healed: and if you see symptoms that do not frighten you, and you hope for salvation, then begin its treatment.
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	That is, if he comes to you wounded at first with the wound: and it is in the days of winter, then it is necessary that you strive for the removal of the bone on the fourteenth day according to every disposition.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	And if it is in the days of summer, then it is necessary that you remove the bone before the seventh day, before what is under the bone from the cloth rots, and those symptoms occur that we have mentioned.
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	That if the fracture of the bone has already reached the cloth touching the brain, and is small, and attracted: then it is necessary that you cut the broken and worn part according to what I tell you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	And it is, that you should lance the wound of a head: and remove the cloth from over the mouth as much as possible for you: and according to the shape of the wound, and what is light on the weak.
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	If it happens to you at the detection of bone bleeding blood, or hot abscess: then place it with what is necessary.
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	And it is, that you fill the place with infused cloths in vinegar and rose oil: and make the wound rest, until the abscess sets, and you are secure from bleeding.
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	Then begin in the healing of the bone, and removal of it.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	And that is done according to one of two ways.
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	One way indeed is, that you cut the bone with an Incisor with a sharp edge: and this is its form.
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	Another way is, that you administer another Incisor after the first one slightly wider: and this is its form.
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	Then also administer another Incisor even wider than the second.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	And the second way is, that you have a number of different Incisors with you: some of which are wider to certain ones, and some of them shorter to certain ones: and they are in the last extreme of their sharpness, and they are from iron or steel: and use ease in percussion on the Incisor, so that it does not shake the head, and it does not hurt it.
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	But if the bone is strong and hard: then it is necessary, that you make holes in its circumference before you administer Incisors, with drills which are called Terebra not penetrating deep: and they are not so called unless because they do not pass beyond the end of the fleshy part to that which is after it: because the tip of the Terebro is round on top of that which is under his sharp head, like a margin, and a small circle prevents submerging and passing through the density of the bone.
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	And it is suitable for you to take from these drill bits a large number, each of which corresponds to the thickness and density of the bone, until you have every possible skull drill: whose sharp end length and brevity in length should correspond to the thickness and density of that skull.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	And this is the form of three types of drill bits or trephines.
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	However, the quality of drilling around a broken bone is: that you place the drill on the bone, and rotate it with your fingers, until you know that the bone has been penetrated.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	Then change the drill to another location, and place what is between all the holes in the thickness of the radius, or approximately that.
Deinde incide cum Incisoriis quod est inter omne foramen ex osse: et fac illud subtilius quam potes super illud ex fine leuitatis, sicut diximus, donec eradices os, aut manu tua, aut cum aliquo alio ex quibusdam instrumentis, quae parasti ad illud: sicut tenaliae, et forpices subtiles.	Then cut with the chisel what is between all the holes from the bone: and make it as thin as possible on that from the fine end, as we said, until the roots of the bone, or by your hand, or with some other of those instruments which you have prepared for that: such as thin tenaille chisels and fine forceps.
Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	And it is necessary to guard against all cautions, that the drill or chisel does not touch anything from those.
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	When therefore you are drilling around the bone and it has been separated from those, if it is continuous with that, and you have extracted it, it is necessary to cut, and equal the end of it which remains in the bone with another similar chisel.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	However, it should be thinner and more delicate than other chisels.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	If there remains anything small from the bones and fragments: then take them with ease, with that which is at your disposal from among those instruments.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	Then care for the wound after that with lint and ointments which we said.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	Here is another method of operation, entirely different from the previous one, which is quite distant from causing fear: this method was mentioned by Galen and highly praised by him, and this is his statement about it.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	It is necessary for you to begin by carefully exposing the part of the bone where the fracture is more severe and more apparent: until you have exposed that part and placed the end of this lens-shaped incisor under it, whose shape is as follows.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	The lens-shaped part does not cut anything, and the sharp part of it advances on both sides of it in length, as you can see: so that the lens-shaped part is pressed against the bone, with its sharp part facing the bone.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	Then strike on the incisor with a small mallet from one side until you have cut through the entire bone with ease, as it rolls: and you will be secure from any accident that you fear entirely.
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	And if the healer were not more foolish than other people, and less knowledgeable about it, and not asleep, then if there remained any part of the bone attached to the cloth in certain places, he would cut it off from it with the end of this lens-shaped incisor, and free it from it with ease.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	It is freed from it without harm, and without fear.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	And if the fracture of the bone does not penetrate to the cloth, and what is cut off from the bone is its face, and there remain in it roughness and fine splinters: then you must scrape off that roughness, and remove those fine splinters with small rasps of various sizes, which you prepared earlier, so that it is possible for you to administer to them in every suitable place, and to make them straighter and more suitable according to the purpose of the operation, and the fractured bone, and its shape.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	And it is necessary that your assistants, in the ratio of your first cutting of the root's mouth, should shave them wider than those of the other razor-makers.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	Then use after him with a more subtle one.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	And do not cease to do that according to continuity until you reach the administering of their thinner and more subtle ones.
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	And in each of the remaining cracks of the hair-like parts and the subtle fracture, it is necessary that your assistant should take care, according to that which leads to its rectification.
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	And there is a thing that does not hide over every one, which in this art is whatever study, and it has stood on that which we wrote and showed in the great fractures.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	But if the piece of cloth is detected and retained when you eradicate the mouth: then it is necessary that you should take the linen according to the quantity of the wound, and submerge it in rose oil, and place it on the opening of the wound.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	Then take another linen doubled or tripled, and submerge it in wine and rose oil, and place it on the first linen: and do that as easily as you can over it, so that it does not weigh heavily on him.
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	Then administer above it the wide bandage: and do not tie it unless by the quantity which holds the wound only: and let it go with this care on one day or two days, until you are secure from hot abscess.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	Then dissolve it, and administer after it the medicines with which there is excessive dryness: such as the roots of lilies, and flour of herb, and powder of frankincense, and aristolochia, and similar to them: and it is that you should make from these medicines a powder which is powdered over the wound as they are dry.
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	And it is universally applied in that, it administers every medicine of its property so as to cleanse, and not to bite.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	And it is applied according to your virtue, so that the wound in your healing be clear: nor is there in it the dirt of ointment, nor filthiness.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	Nor do you dismiss the virus to gather in it at all: for when the virus gathers on the cloth of the brain, it corrupts it, and rots it, and there is a great evil after that on the weak one: and now it happens in the head, when the mouth is cleaned by it, especially when the care of it is neglected, blackness on its surface.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	Therefore consider then, if such things happen to the weak one which we said, know that it is certainly harmful.
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	And if blackness does not happen, unless from the medicine which is placed on it, and is in the virtue of that medicine, so as to make that blackness: then it is necessary for you to take from the honey one part, from the red oil three parts, and linen with them cloth.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	Then place it on the head: afterwards care for it with the species of healing which come together, until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	¶ On the restoration of the nose when it is broken.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	Know that they are not broken from the nose except two of its upper parts at once, or one of them: because they are two bones: since below it is cartilaginous, it is not broken, and does not happen to it except wear, and twisting, and swelling.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	If one of the two parts is broken, then it is necessary for you to insert your finger slightly in the nostril, and equal that fracture with your index finger, and thumb deformed, until the nose returns above its natural shape: and do this artfully, with ease.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	And beware, lest that pain of yours occur through your operation on the sick person.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	But if the fracture is in the upper part of the nose, and your finger does not reach it, then it is necessary to equalize the end of the radius, where the swelling is small.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	But if indeed the fracture is in two parts, then do the same as that: and hasten with its restoration on the first day of the fracture, if it is possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	And if not, then after the seventh or tenth day at the heat of pus-filled abscesses.
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	Then introduce a linen strip into the end of the nose, if the fracture is in one part: or introduce two strips if the fracture is in two parts: and let the swelling be of such quantity as to fill the nostril.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	And some of the ancient restorers said that linen strips should be soaked in butter and changed every day.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	But that does not seem to me, rather it is necessary, that the linen strip be soaked in a white powder made with flour of moldova.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	Then let go of the linen strip, until the bone hardens and the cartilage becomes tough.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	And sometimes a goose feather is introduced into the place of the linen strip in the nose, after it has been covered with a soft cloth: and it is made so that it holds the broken nose more strongly, and so that the sick person is not hindered from breathing.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	And this matter is not necessary.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	If you wish, do it: and if you wish, make the linen strips.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	But if it happens to the nose again while you are operating on the hot pus-filled abscess, apply nasal plasters with charcoal, or dissolved cotton in rose oil, or a little from dayquilon.
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	If however, a hot abscess does not occur, then it is necessary to apply a plaster made of the same with wheat flour, and a powder of turpentine, mixed with egg white.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	Then place a soft bandage over it, and do not bind the nose at all.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	If indeed the bones of the nose are broken or crushed, then it is necessary to split them and remove them with the tools that are suitable for them.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	Then cut the wound, and care for it with what covers and heals it, and strengthens it with suitable plasters or ointments.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	If however a wound occurs between the nose, then it is necessary to care for it with leeches: and administer a lead tube until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	Concerning the restoration of the lower jaw when it is broken.
Caput V.	Chapter 5.
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	When the lower jaw is broken, and its fracture is not accompanied by a wound: if it is deformed only, and not broken into two, and care is taken to its insides: then its knowledge is easy.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	Therefore, if the fracture is in the right part, then insert the index finger of the left hand into the weak bone: similarly, if the fracture is in the left jaw, then insert the index finger of the right hand: and push with it the swelling of the fracture inside with ease to the outside with your other hand from the inner part of the bone properly, and with it make it even.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	If however the fracture of the jaw has already been separated into two, then it is necessary to administer extension from both parts, according to straightness: until it is possible to make an evening of it.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	If, however, the commotion or disruption has already occurred in the teeth, then bind them with thread made of gold, silver, or silk, hoping that they will remain intact.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	Then place a broken ceramic over the fractured jaw.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	Then place a double layer of cloth over it, and place a large, well-made stomach button on the cloth: or an equal piece of leather from the sole of a shoe, in the length of the jaw.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	Then bind it from above, according to how the bandage of that type is prepared for you and its application fits, until it is not destroyed: and instruct the weak person to use it with tranquility and quietness: and place his drinks with gentle sips.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	If, however, you estimate that something is already changing the shape in some ways: then hasten and dissolve it on the third day.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	Then correct what has been changed from it, and make plasters of it from the flour of the millstone, with egg white, or with sisami flour, after you have removed the broken ceramic: and place a soft cloth on the plaster.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	While therefore it remains attached to that plaster over it, and the disposition of the bone is not changed, leave it, so that it does not dissolve, until it is healed: or bind the fracture.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	For often this fracture is bound for three weeks.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	But if meanwhile an inflammation hot occurs, then administer to it what we said is often used in the sedation of it, until that inflammation is removed.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	And if the fracture is with a wound, consider.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	For now a piece of bone is already separated from the bone, or from the splinter: then carefully take it out with you that suits you in the removal of those from the tools.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	If indeed the wound opening is constricted, then enlarge it with a lancet according to the amount of your need.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	Then when you have removed that bandage, and there remains none of it, then sue the wound opening, if it is wide: and if not, place upon it some of those plasters which are suitable for that, and cover it, until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	¶ On the restoration of the clavicle, when it is broken.
Caput VI.	Chapter 6.
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	The clavicle is most often broken from the anterior part on the side of the shoulder, and its fracture occurs in one of three ways.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	For indeed it is broken and separated into two, except that some bandages occur in it: and it is easier for its restoration.
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	Or thus, that some bandages occur in the bone of the bandage: and it is more difficult for its restoration.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	Or thus, that it is a fracture with a wound.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	And operation in it when the fracture is without wound, is, that you make present to be two assistants, that one of them holds the following instrument which follows the clavicle broken, and the other extends the neck towards the part.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	Then equal the fracture with your fingers, until it becomes its form, according to what is necessary: and there is not in it protrusion, nor hollowness.
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	If you need more extension, then it is necessary, that you place under the infirm sphere of the tip a ball of cloth, or of wool: and its size should be according to the amount of your need: and extend, and elevate the clavicle, and cut the ball with your hand, until equal the fracture, according to what is necessary.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	If you cannot draw the tip of the fork to the outside, because it has reached the depth, then the weak one must be bent over his shoulder and you place a pillow under his arm in the size of a medium, and press his helper's arm downwards until the tip of the fork that is at the depth is lifted upwards. Then straighten the fracture and make it even with your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	But if you feel a broken piece of the fork and it moves, then you must drill into it and extract the broken piece of the fork with ease.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	But if it is stuck in the bone, then use your skills in the incision and one of the prepared incisors to hold the instrument that will support the saw under the fork, which is a tool made of wood or iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	It resembles a spiral that does not have a concavity.
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	Its width should be according to what you need from the size of the bone and its shape.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	The length of it, however, should also be according to what is possible for you in the operation.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	It should have two ends, as you see: and one end should be wide and the other narrow.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	But if the wound that you cut when you extracted the broken piece of bone is wide and you want to prevent infection, then gather two lips of the wound with stitches.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	But if the wound is small and you fear infection, then fill the wound with cloth and cotton according to the size of the cut.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	But if an infection occurs, then pour oil with roses, vinegar, and wine over it and place it on the wound.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	When the fracture of a bone is without wound and without incision, it is treated by applying a plaster made from flour milled from grain mixed with egg yolk onto the bone.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	And place a soft bandage on top of it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	Then place a sphere under its splint, if you have one.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	Then take a hollow reed, that is, the one held by the Saracens, which is very long: and its width should be the size of one palm or about that.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	Then place a double-layered pad and plaster on top of it.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	Then take a thin board, the width of which is three fingers and the length similarly.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	Then wrap it in cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	Then wrap the cloth with the board in the place where the hollow reed falls on the fracture and the affected area.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	Then place the hollow reed on the fracture as it was wrapped, and wrap it around his neck, and under the splint of the healthy person and under the splint of the sick person: and reduce it over all parts, and however you see that the bandage holds the fracture, that is the correct bandage: and this should not be hidden from you, and the whole, so that the board does not move above the broken bone.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	And for this reason, it is necessary to look at the sick person every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	Whenever the ligament becomes soft and you see the board already moving away: then correct it and tighten the ligament.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	Then place the sick person's pillow on his back, and place a small pad under his splint at night, so that when he is lifted up with his aid, it is on his side.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	Therefore, the fracture of the clavicle is raised by elevating the arm.
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	Tie his arm to his neck: and do not untie the bandage, unless it is necessary due to an emergency, such as skin irritation or an abscess, up to twelve days.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	Then reapply the plaster, if you see his face towards that direction.
